This anime is one of those anime that isn't meant to be taken seriously. It's one of those that is meant to make you relate to the characters and/or give you satisfaction. A very similar anime to this is Himouto! Umaru-chan. 
Plot: 5/10
The plot of it is that the MC has been writing a light novel where the illustrator is some unknown person that goes by the name 'Eromanga'. He doesn't realize that Eromanga is actually his little sister (which is not his biological sister). I won't be talking about what happens later because it's kinda spoiler filled. The story focuses on a couple ofcharacters who are all either otakus, authors, publishers or illustrators. Honestly the concept of having a story focused on an otaku character has been done before and is slowly becoming more common. The story is easy to understand (at least for anime fans and/or manga fans) but that's cause it's not complex. I do feel like it has been done before but not in this way (???). I would also like to mention the fat guy that runs between the transitions each episode, I thought that was a nice thing they keep. I gave it a 5 (mediocre) due to it not being something unbelievably original but still not something that's overdone.


Art: 9/10

The art in this is actually very well done. Although due to the art and story most of the time when I was watching this (especially at the scenes when one of the authors is bragging) I kept thinking how the animators felt. I mean they did have to animate this series which makes publishing a work and drawing seem so easy (I mean Eromanga is like 12 and can draw that in like 5 minutes) while the animators probably can't see their family most of the time and almost never get recognition.


Sound: 8/10

I'm not a musician but I do have to admit that the music is quite good. I know it's not Yuri on Ice levels or Your Lie in April levels but is quite fitting for the series.


Character:5/10

The series has quite good characters. Their biggest fault is usually that they are unoriginal or simply unrealistic. When reviewing anime you have to realize that it is animation, so they make everything quite extra (face expressions, emotions, voice acting ect.) to make stuff entertaining. But seriously Eromanga is 12 and can draw that well?! Elf-Yamada is like 14 and is one of the most successful authors in upcoming light novels ?! And how does the MC keep his writing on check and his school life on and manages to have friends?? I feel like this is due to the writers of the show being too old to understand the stuff you can and can't do at a young age. I'm around the age of the characters and I do feel like this is too extra. 


Enjoyment:5/10

If it was any other anime I would of dropped it already. But their is after all something pulling me to watch one more episode if you know what I mean. I honestly think it's the hangcliffs at the ends of most of the episodes. BUT HOW? I don't feel attached to the story nor the characters. How is this possible?


BRIEF HISTORY:


pros:

-you might relate to the characters if you're a writer or any type of artist

-the animation is great

-the music is fine

-you get attached to the series somehow

-if you want to get to know anime and manga this might be good for you

-overall it seems like a weird concept but it is pretty relateble to some people


cons:

-the story is pretty boring for the first few episodes

-characters are bland

-honestly if half of the characters weren't lolis this would be such a flop

This piece of writing is based on the viewing experience of the first 4 episodes of Eromanga-sensei.
To be honest I really don't understand why this series is getting so much hate.
I understand that there is no real plot, the character are not deep and the protagonist is the usual light novel protagonist. But I don't think people watching this show come into it expecting a interesting plot with unique characters.
I read CoquiEnthusiast review of the show in which he/she wanted to vent his/her anger regarding the show and I get that most of the points he made are fair but to be fair to theshow-


-The animation is not that bad.(Relative to some of the other shows that have come out this season it's quite good. Eg: Clockwork planet, Alice to Zouruko etc)

-The soundtrack gets a passing grade too.

-I too fell the displeasure experienced by CoquiEnthusiast due to the unnecessary sexualization of the characters of the show, but at this point the anime industry is in such a place that most of the shows based in the harem/ecchi genre all share this common theme and also most shows based out of highschool also share this theme.

-Despite all this, if you just want to shut your brain and watch some stupid shit then this show itself is not that bad.


I also understand the comparison to Oreimo and it's blatantly obvious where this plot is going but I think the people who watch this shows every week already know this.

As a anime fan, I do expect much better from the anime industry, I myself also hope that shows like Ping pong, Code Geass, Haikyuu S1,S2 ,Berserk 1997-98, Parasite are produced every season and that I can take pleasure in watching them.


I'm not here to say that Eromanga-sensei is great anime in fact I don't even think it's a good anime and i'm sure everyone will forget about it by the end of the season. I myself won't be watching this anime anymore. But If some one wants to enjoy Eromanga-sensei I have nothing against them. After all if people can watch tentacle hentai why can't they watch this.


After reading all this the reader may be wondering what I wanted to convey through this. To be honest nothing much really, I just wanted to put forward my thoughts on this show.

BTW I really like the OP of the show.

P.S: Sorry for mentioning CoquiEnthusiast review again and aging in the above text. I understand that most of the readers may not have read his/her review. His/Her review of Eromanga-sensei should be up on the MAL page of Eromanga-sensei.

The comedic adventures of a young light novel author and his "shut in" hopelessly bashful sister. On the surface, this claims to be a slice of life story about sibling bonding, but most of us know better than that. If you're familiar with the Oreimo series by the same author, you probably have no doubt where this is heading. For the rest of you, this is a normal high schooler SoL with an "adult life" twist and a whole lot of cuteness. There are deeper serious undertones and meaningful emotional scenes in this one, but the show rarely budges from a shameless, relaxing, adventurous moodwith tons of laughs along the way. If I had to say something good about this show it would be the very likable cast. From the very start character premises are very easy to accept and like, with a wide variety of cute, bizarre and seriously funny personalities. Animation flows beautifully, with plenty of realistic detail in movements, gestures, and dancing that at times can seem one-of-a-kind. Art is magnificent with stunning effort put into the smallest of details in backgrounds and on characters with ample use of great colors. Character art is very pleasing to the eye and filled well thought out and impressive details from head to toe. Dialogue in scenes is very informal and relatable, it can be repetitive at times though. If I had to say something bad about this show it would the weak plot. Not much screentime is put into seriously working toward the plot, with hours and hours of goofing off and antics that may seem childish to many. The plot is repetitive any doesn't seem to head in any interesting or surprising direction. The imaginary world of Eromananga Sensei is quite small and has very few details, it can make the show feel monotonous. 

Fair Warning however: if shameless fan service bothers you, don't bother watching. if dirty sibling stories enfuriate you, immediately contact your local police department and ask to have them ban this show in your country (or just don't watch it). Favorite characters: Elf, Sagiri. I give it a 7.5/10.


TL:DR Version: Goofy, very funny, cute, warm, SoL with a lot of smiles and sexiness. Don't watch if you hate fan service. Great visuals. Bone-dry, repetitive plot.

First things first. My "reviews" system is explained on a blog entry. Which can be found through my profile.
------
✦Story
You know, I do love these straightforward and bright pseudo-romance series with small twists in them. And in this particular Anime the twist was that most female cast were young girls, who were ero artist in nutshell. A joyful adventure of young lewd minds, who actually are still inexperienced and pure. That twist alone made this anime fun for me. Bless art of eros.
Now, as usual these type of shows are extremely minimal in story adventure. As they function as usual as advertisement for the source material.Basically, once you finish the Anime it pretty much gives you general gist of the world, characters, setting and so on. A big prologue in Animated form. "If you want to know more, read the LN" basically this type of thing. I'm fine and used to it, but obviously I won't touch the LN as I cannot be bothered to read in general. Although I do hope all young lewd minds will find their vanilla soulmate and be lewd together until death them parts. Being lewd is fine as long you stay true to love and intimacy and won't become a ***t.


Anyhow, to sum it up. Story is presented in straightforward and bright manner as usual with these kinds of Anime. For what it is, I found it entertaining as it had fun setting and really cute characters. Do not expect story progressing too far, as mentioned these types of Anime are basically introductory to their source material and likelihood seeing them fully adapted is quite minimal.


✦Art & Sound

Simple, fun, colorful and straightforward. I have nothing else to add.


✦Character

We have a bunch of cute stereotypes that also have their "annoying" side. An extreme shut-in, who is as well quite lewd and jealous. A tsundere ojou-sama, who is a bit tad too tiring. Not my perfect tsundere. And a bit quiet, sadistic, selfish and oddly angry kimono girl. Nevertheless, all of the female cast pretty much has absolutely adorable side as well.


Side characters also were pretty fun stereotypes and the main guy was, well the usual "good guy, but a bit awkward" stereotype.


In the end, I enjoyed them all.

And I do ship main character with Tomoe. Loved their minimal moments.


✦Enjoyment & Overall

I did mention already everything that is needed. It is a straightforward, pseudo-romance, harem with a little twist to it. Why I call it "pseudo" is simply it doesn't really progress anywhere relationships'wise as this Anime is pretty much introduction to the world

Service was as well nice. It wasn't visually too lewd, but rather it gave more to imagination. Which in this Anime was a superb balance.


Joyful, bright, fun. Bless art of eros.

My first feeling when I was watching this show was really different from what I think now.
You know, Eromanga-sensei is one of these show that is so incredibly horrible that it actually becomes entertaining. However, that kind of feeling doesn't last long. That's why I went from totally amazed and wondering how far the show would go with the awkward suggestive scenes and the absolutely not sane brother-sister relationship to bored as hell.
But I had to finish it. I needed to write this review, and I it wouldn't be honest to write a review without finishing it beforehand.
So Eromanga-sensei is about a highschool guy whois also a siscon who discovers that his cute shut-in little sister (they're not blood-related, keep that in mind, it's important) is the one who actually draws the erotic art for his light-novels. As a good main character for a show like this, this young boy has the charisma of a cup of cold coffee, while being irritatingly dense, of course. And the show is supposed to be about the evolution of the little sister (they do not have any biological bood whatsoever, keep that in mind) and her opening to the world, except she doesn't ! Of course, you'd remove 50% of the jokes otherwise. \n
So this lucky bastard encounters a few girls during the 12 episodes, going from the cliché tsundere, who actually tells him "I-it's not like I like you or anything b-baka !" for f*cking real to the twelve year-old girl who tells him she loves dicks, and he is regularly put in embarassing situations.\n
And, that's, it.\n
Then you have the festival episode, the field trip episode, the tournament episoode and so on. The only thing missing is a final episode actually. Even though the first few episodes let us think there would be some evolutions in the relations of the characters or in the characters themselves, nothing came.\n\n\n
So, well, at first it was fun, I even told a few of my friends "go for it dude, you're seriously in for a treat with this show". Because I'll be honest, the otherworldly scenes like a little girl playing piano in an abandonned mansion totally naked without a freaking reason, the fact that THEY AREN'T RELATED BY BLOOD IF YOU FORGOT, or the simple fact that it's an anime about a little girl drawing porn unironically amazed me... In the first 6 episodes. After that, even though the show  continues to do better (I should say worse) every episode, you're just bored. The hype for a shitty show can't possibly last long. Thus, I've had huge troubles getting myself to watch the three last episodes.\n\n
So, as a conclusion, if you're fine with dense characters, stupid jokes, a buttload of dumb clichés and an MC who is a fully assumed siscon, then go, this show is exactly what you were looking for. Otherwise, I'm pretty sure everybody here has something better to do. Not me though, I wouldn't be here writting reviews otherwise.

I’m not entirely sure what exactly compelled me to start Eromanga sensei. Perhaps I wanted to know why exactly were people completely shocked about how explicit the show was (when the writer and studio are the exact same as OreImo). Perhaps I wanted to see if OreImo’s writer fixed his craft. Perhaps I just wanted something to rage on. Whatever the case is, it succeeded in delivering on most of my expectations and is easily one of the worst TV anime to air in recent memory.
It’s difficult to discuss Eromanga without discussing OreImo, so I’ll be spoiling major parts of OreImo. Not like any saneperson would care, but spoilers ahoy.


Eromanga-sensei is basically the fusion of the worst aspects of OreImo (not like that show was any good, but it at least took time to become complete garbage), combined with the pervertedness and general stupidity of your standard incest doujin/hentai. Unlike most of those, Eromanga-sensei also caters to lolicons, which makes it appeal to the lowest common denominator in basically every single way.


This show’s entire existence is to shove fanservice down the viewer’s throat at literally every single opportunity. The cast largely consists of girls who aren’t even teenagers, but you’d never guess if you saw how shamelessly parades various clothing items…to put it mildly. Sex jokes are in every corner, and while I like my sex jokes as much as the next guy (for…reasons) they’re all tasteless and incredibly unoriginal here.


The story is a rehash of OreImo with sprinkles of other shows in between. Not like that taking influence from other works is necessarily an issue, but this is OreImo we’re talking about. You know, the story that ended literally with a sister and brother getting married and the main character shooting down every girl who likes him to bang his sister. I can give it the smallest of credit since I think it’s actually more honest about its incest shenanigans, unlike OreImo which had the first half of season 1 being wildly different in tone from the rest of the show.


The characters are rehashes of OreImo’s cast with absolutely nothing to make them distinct from their counterparts there. The cast even has characters that feel like a combination of characters from that show, which might have worked out for less intelligent minds if it weren’t for the fact that OreImo’s cast literally walks by and it cements in the mind of the viewer that we’re basically staring at almost the same cast. What I’m trying to say is that these characters are garbage; they act in illogical and ridiculous ways and make fuck all sense.


Animation quality is decent but nothing exceptional, looking almost exactly like OreImo did (Seeing a pattern here?) and the character designs looking the same, with the added benefit of the A-1 Pictures same-face syndrome and even Claris singing the opening…*sigh* This is just season 3 of OreImo, isn’t it?


So Eromanga sensei, is for the lack of a better phrase, complete garbage. It’s the kind of thing I’d recommend to make ISIS members watch to torture them into submission, but I wouldn’t recommend to any remotely ordinary person and is a pile of trash that should be buried in the lowest pits of hell.

Normally, I like all anime that have something to present. For example, you give me a sibling romantic comedy, (even though I dislike such story lines) I will give it a good score as long as it has good, solid character development and a steady pace with nothing rushed going into it. Hell, I might even suggest it to people.
However, this anime is, to me, highly infuriating. People might critisize me for this review because I gave it a low score, however, allow me to explain. 
Originally, I liked the anime's opening song. I liked it’s art, animation and character design. Let me remind you,the protagonist, eromanga sensei [Masamune’s little sister] is a cutesy character and most people liked her because of her design. I admit, I did too.  But, after watching this anime, I kinda pity her and don't like her as much as I did before starting this show.


I have no problems with cutesy characters — although, I prefer badass characters— so that isn't my main reason for disliking this show. I have several reasons as to why I hate this show, so much. Firstly, let's start with the abundance of adults in the anime. Middle Schoolers and highschooler’s don't have their parents taking care of their child. I mean, fine I can handle the sibling's situation. But, what about the teenager living next door to them? She lives alone, throughout the anime, there's not a even a hint of her siblings or parents or relatives taking care of her, by any sorts. Yes, she has a brother, but what kind of brother let's his sister (who BTW is of thirteen years old) live alone in a huge house, and live separately without him? 


Secondly, these girls willingly lift their skirts up and let Sagiri draw their facial expressions, panties and etc. 


Thirdly, the quote&; sibling romantic comedy "e; is no where to be found. The brother hasn't seen his sister for years and once she opens the door, they talk and after a few days he confesses his feelings for her?


Oh, and the probably the thing I hate most, is the fact that thirteen year olds talk about dicks, ask people to strip and the sister draws a hentai manga with a fucked-up dick. 


Even though, this anime is supposed to be about Sagiri, she gets less screen time then supporting characters. We never see any character relationship build and don't see how anything progresses.


Overall, I hate this anime. I don't recommend anyone to watch this, it sucks.

There’s only one anime that managed to get my blood boiling more than Sword Art Online, and that anime is Eromanga Sensei. Going into it, I had a feeling that this anime wasn’t going to be anything revolutionary, but I didn’t expect to find nothing but bad writing, cliched, beaten to death scenarios, and above all else, this overwhelming feeling like you’re being disgustingly predatory. I’ve never been one to turn down good fanservice; if anything, I encourage it (as long as it’s done well), and I don’t think I’ve ever been this uncomfortable watching a fanservice show. Showing me the panties of some 16year old high school girl? Okay, fine. But 12 year olds? Where do we draw the line with this shit?


Is this what we’ve come to? Eating up the most bland, badly written, and pandery piece of shit that we can find all for a couple of cute girls- who are, by the way, DISGUSTINGLY underage? Like, I’m talking creepy upshirt shots for no reason at all aside from “Wow, don’t you want to fuck this 12 year old?” Loli jokes were funny for a little bit I guess, but when we’re at a point as a community where lewding girls that literally look straight outta the womb is a really funny joke, yeah fuck that. 


Story: 1/10


I honestly can’t believe how much this show is banking on the success of Oreimo. But, unlike Oreimo, this show feels totally and completely hollow. While Oreimo definitely had its flaws, it had consistent and- for the most part- well written characters. This anime is nothing but an excuse to animate some young girls with their panties out and sell as many dakimakuras and figures of Elf and Sagiri as they possibly can. Every calculated joke screams “Turn me into a reaction gif!! Make me this seasons Big Meme!!” and it all just leaves me with a bad taste in my mouth.


Starting out this show, it’s made clear right off the bat that both Masamune and Sagiri want to fuck each other and, even though it’s presented as a harem, Sagiri and Masamune are going to end up together. What follows is 12 episodes of this anime jerking us back and forth through stupid misunderstandings meant to fill this anime out with as much fanservice-y bulk as they can. All for a final episode that wraps up absolutely nothing and attempts to provide absolutely no closure, instead leaving me feeling like the show actually spat in my face. This show is all around badly written, sometimes changing character’s personalities and motivations for no reason except to move the plot along to the next part (which is always just another excuse for fanservice), especially during the beach trip arc. And worst of all, with such a generic, fanservice-centered plot, this show is a chore to watch. It’s just so bland. Everything that you could possibly want out of this show has been done before in better, way less predatory ways.


Animation: 4/10


While I do think that Eromanga looks alright, for a show centered around how sexy and cute their loli characters are, I found myself thinking constantly that the characters were badly designed. Maybe it’s because I’m not a pedophile looking to watch an anime about 12 year olds with my dick in my hand, but even Sagiri, who was animated by someone whose entire job was to make her look sexy, was not attractive. Elf, who wears poofy lolita dresses and elf ears, (and is very obviously supposed to be the Kuroneko of this show) looks stupid, and I don’t remember ever thinking while watching this show that she was cute. The majority of the smoother animation was used for creepy upshirt shots of Sagiri drawing or high detailed shots- down to the BABY FAT ON HER BODY- of her changing into a sexy outfit for her brother. When I tell people about how disgusted I am by the fanservice in this show, I show them the very beginning of episode 5, because that’s all you need to see to know that this show is just trying to cash in on pedophiles who use the excuse that “Well, it’s just fiction!” to justify their behavior. Being into 12 year old girls with baby fat still on their body, and animating long scenes of her rolling around on her bed like a toddler with cutesy mobile music that sounds like it was recorded on a toy piano is downright gross. It does nothing but normalize wanting to fuck underage girls. I’m not trying to be preachy, but when is enough enough? When do we sit back and realize that the anime community harbors pedophiles and normalizes wanting to have sex with young girls? There is a huge problem with pedophilia in Japan, and shows like this, that make and sell sexy merch of their extremely underage characters, just normalize and send the message that there’s nothing wrong with wanting to fuck 10 year olds. And anime studios that see the success that this show brought them and all the money that they got from it’s creation? It just makes other anime studios think that loli fanservice is what we want now, and it’s just gross. Give me some huge honking Babonkers any day, but leave the underdeveloped babies out of it. It’s just super gross. I’ll get off my soapbox now. 


Sound 3/10


Not much to say about this. Nothing to write home about here.


Overall Enjoyment 1/10


Do yourself a favor and skip this show. I guess if you want to watch a boring Oreimo clone with predatory fanservice and shitty plot, have at it, but if you’re looking for anything with just a bit of substance, this is a show to avoid. If you like watching train wrecks and then bitching about how shitty they are, hey, maybe you’ll get something out of this one, but I promise that it’s not worth watching the whole show. Instead, go watch Koi Kaze, an incest anime that actually has interesting things to say about how society views incestual relationships and well written characters to make you 10x more invested than this show ever could.

The 'imouto genre' is a very peculiar sub-genre to the whole moe craze that we have in anime today.  Mostly relying on the forbidden fruit of romantic sibling relationships, most of these shows tend to have ankle-deep plotlines with heavy reliance on fanservice and your typical misunderstanding plots in order to fill out its runtime.  If I may be honest here, Eromanga-sensei really is no different.
Story: Masamune Izumi is an LN author in high school.  Due to familial circumstances, he must now support himself and his little stepsister, Sagiri, so that the two of them may continue living together.  With Sagirishutting herself in her room 24/7, Masamune has a hard time connecting with her until he finds out one day that his little sister is actually the illustrator for his books, Eromanga-sensei.  And thus, hilarity (I guess) ensues.  


The story for Eromanga-sensei relies primarily on two things: the on-going plot of our protagonist trying to make a new book, and a harem comprised of entirely middle school girls.  When combined together, the show creates a decently meshed story, but is ultimately nothing too special as a lot of the dialogue repeating similar lines to each other to boast the audience's appeal to root for the main characters and their dreams, and many of the scenes and episodes are repeated ecchi gags like the beach episode, unnecessary challenges, and the girls hiding their true feelings for a greater portion of the series.  Not only that, but the show puts in far too many attempts at creating dramatic or interesting character introductions that are honestly more cringe-inducing than welcome to see.  (Looking at you, Muramasa.)  


While the show is at face value, a cheap rehash of many of what would considered to be the norm in anime, the show does have several genuinely cute moments with the second to last episode in particular being the highlight of the entire series as it explains a backstory that I guess we never really asked for.  (Was still nice to see.)  On top of that, the show's overall playful nature with its character interactions and lighter storyline leans it more towards a piece of fluff entertainment, so expecting more than what's on the cover is asking for too much.  


However I'm not really keen on the ending since all they did to finish the series off was to chuck in a throwaway episode that had no handling on the main story.  If anything, they probably should've just left episode 12 to be an OVA or something cause comparatively, it follows it own storyline, and it's just weird for the audience to expect some kind of conclusion when really you just leave it on some kind of weird cliffhanger that doesn't make anyone at all very happy.


Overview:

+  Actually nice backstory that caps everything off

+/-  Pretty much what'd you expect for a little sister/harem series

-  Last episode is worthless in terms of continuity


Characters: As expected with a harem-based series, the cast or Eromanga-sensei consists primarily of the main, dense protagonist, the girls who he trails behind, and a bunch of side characters whose only purpose is to add to the story in a minimal way.


As expected, Masamune Izumi is your typical run of the mill harem protagonist.  Well, not so much 'run of the mill', just not particularly all that interesting.  With his dream being to have one of his works get turned into an anime and getting the chance to watch said anime with his little sister, Masamune ends up being less of your typical dense harem protag, but more of one that is aware of each of the girls' feelings, but doesn't really act on them.  He wants his little sister to be able to comfortably step out of her room, but does so without changing much of the status quo of things with any sort of foreseeable impact later on down the line.  Ultimately, he does have several aspects of him that make him more interesting than some other harem protags, but not enough to make him not only his own character or anyone really interesting to watch.


As for Sagiri, or Eromanga-sensei (an alias that she refuses to acknowledge despite the fact that she came up with it herself), Sagiri plays the role of the cute little sister who secretly loves her brother but is too shy and scared to say or do anything despite getting jealous of all the attention her brother gets cause literally everyone he hangs out with on a daily basis is female.  Despite being a 'main character', Sagiri's existence really is more of a glorified supporting character.  Because of her shut-in nature, she never leaves the house, and as such relies mostly on video calls to give her a majority of her interactions with other characters in the series.  As a result, Sagiri's screentime is severely lacking for a 'main character', so it feels very strange to even call her that.  I do however find her closet pervert antics quite amusing.  It's just funny to see seeing this 13 year old girl act like an old man half the time because of her fascination of women's underwear and the like.  


The rest of the harem, Elf and Muramasa, actually have a much bigger role in the series than the supposed heroine.  Playing the loud, aggressive narc and the more soft-spoken chuuni, the duo of these two authors create the rest of Masamune's harem and act as comrades in arms to our main character, thus giving them more screentime.  While the series provides us with some backstory and explanation to how these girls become authors, their characters similar to the rest of the cast, don't really change all that much.  The comedic nature of the series leaves their characters stagnant in order to keep their appeal, really only cropping up new aspects of them at the end when Ithere's nothing related to the plot of writing a book happening.  


As mentioned before, the rest of the cast doesn't really do much.  Consisting of a middle school girl who outright says she loves dick, various editors, the guy author who pretty much only shows up at the end and barely does anything, and other characters of similar importance, the side cast is there to enrich the cast, and nothing else.  


Overview:

+ Main cast (and harem) each have some interesting aspect to them

-  Stagnant characters

-  Side cast practically does nothing


Art: Produced by A-1, Eromanga-sensei looks bright, is quite clean, and is general standard fare for the company.  Using a heavy moe-stylized appearance, the whole point of the artstyle is to look cute and appealing to the audience.  Nothing really outstanding about it, but nothing really that bad.  


I do want to fact that because the show literally has 'ero' in its name, Eromanga-sensei is indeed a fanservice show.  With many gratuitous shots of underage girls, from beach scenes to underwear, thigh shots, etc...it's pretty much impossible to avoid any kind of blatant fanservice when the word 'erotic' is written on the box.  So if you're not a fan of fanservice, probably not something for you.


Overview:

+ Clean, consistent quality

+/- Quite a lot of fanservice (Depends on your opinion of fanservice)


Sound: The OST for Eromanga-sensei isn't all that special.  Both its OP "Hitorigoto" and ED "adrenaline!!!" are cheery pop songs that sound nice, but are ultimately quite generic in the end.  The ED is a little more poppy than the OP, but they're still the same kind of song.  


Personal Enjoyment: If I were to describe Eromanga-sensei, I'd say it's 'enjoyable'.  Nothing about it is spectacular, ground-breaking, or really all that special.  It's the show of the season that people devote the season's memes to because of just how painfully average it is.  Personally, I don't really have anything directed towards it: no vendetta, no appreciation, just an entirely average "meh" to the whole thing.  


Did I like this series?  


If anything, I find Elf, amusing.  She was always my favorite of the three girls because while her bold and brazen attitude can be annoying, she was the most consistent character and was more honest than the others.  I also like Sagiri's 'old man' antics.  Her being a perverted 13 year old was always amusing for some reason.


What didn't I like about this series?


Aside from the last episode being a throwaway, Muramasa's introduction was one of the shoddiest character introductions I've ever seen.  Especially when you learn why things played out the way they did, it just boggles the mind with how or why things turned out that way.  (Also a certain cameo at the end of episode 11 is just...no.  Why do you remind me of that?)


Would I recommend this show?


If you're looking for something kinda trashy and not expecting much from it, Eromanga-sensei fits the bill quite well.  Again, the show is really more of a piece of entertainment than any kind of impressive story or overarching plot, so don't really expect much when watching it.  Personally, I don't think it's bad enough to be panned, but it's not really good enough to be worth anything but a timekiller, so my standing on its merit is that it's something that's ok for when you have the downtime for it.

siblings
a word used to describe the beautiful relationship shared by two people , who are bound the mutual feeling of love and respect. But can this unconditional love develop into something past this sibling bond? So, Eromanga sensei is an anime based on a Light novel of the same name  written by, as i mentioned before, Tsukasa fushimi. Now you must have known bout this guy because ofhis previous work, Oreimo... and don't get me wrong , I am a Big fan of Oreimo, its one of my favorite Light novels of all time. But even I am not sure why would

he write such a trash for his next work.


Now, the story follows Isumi masamune, a high schooler who is also secretly a Light novel author. He lives alone with his 12 year old S-T-E-P sister, who is a hikikomori doesn't come out of her room. The illustrations for his novels are done by a artist named "Eromanga Sensei", and as his nme suggests.. he is famous for drawing erotic illustrations.. tho refuses to acknowledge the fact. So one day , through one of his live streams , Eromanga sensei's identity was revealed to Masamune.. and guess who was it ... It was his little sister Sagiri( woo.. i would've never guessed that). He also meets various other light novel authors and, surprisingly all of them are  High schoolers (because... anime). We then follow a story which seems to go nowhere and has all the cute girls falling for masamune for no reason but he still want his sister..( because ...anime)


Now,  I think that that characters are the best... or rather the least worst thing in the anime. The main protagonist, Masamune is a part time light novel author and a full time siscon and wishes to go full time on both. Jokes aside, he is one of the generic dense characters with no personality at all but he has a talent for  writing.. tho most of his work gets rejected. Thus he has very low self esteem but has a believe that one day he will make money out of writing and can support his sister  independently .He really isn't a bad character and also has a strong sense of responsibility in him tho he still is dense as fuck.


Sagiri..... Now this character was quite popular for being extremely cute and moe... but fuck.. i don't like her.She is one the worst female leads i have ever seen. Besides being cute, i can't think of a many  good thing about her.. she is somewhat of a tsundere and has a brat like personality.. she knows that masamune loves her but still acts this way towards him ( but i guess thats how tsundere are) . She is good at drawing erotic illustrations ( hmm.. a 12 year old loli drawing lewd illustrations... seems legit) and she also has a weird fetish for looking at other at other girl's panties.. but she can't leave her room so orders her Nii-san to do it.She speaks really soft and needs to use a mike for speaking to people.And tho both she was even confessed by masamune... she rejected him for some reason and now .. when she actually starts to like him.. she wants him to confess to her  and doesn't want to say it herself. Trust me i Can't ship them.. i just can't.


Yamada elf was a really interesting character and TBH my favorite in the entire anime. She is a famous light novel author who started living next door to masamune. At first she was bit brat like... but later her attitude changed when she befriends masamune and they start spending a lot of time togather. She is really passionate when it comes to writing and often gives tips to masamune too. She eventually falls for him and even confesses to him in episode 9...(watch that episode.. you'll love her .. trust me)

Tho masamune really likes her but he says he is in love with sagiri so he can't reciprocate her feelings. Muramasa is another light novel author who has sold around 10 million copies. She says that she was inspired by masamune for writing and doesn't care about her sales and just wants to write for fun. She also loves masamune and had confessed to him.... ho was rejected.


The art of the series is really good.( as expected of A1) . But they really got lazy when it came to character design. most of the characters seem like a cheap copy of the ones in oreimo (might be because the illustrator was same for both series). The sound track is pretty OK with really nothing to praise or complain about.


In the end... Eromanga sensei is really a crappy series with little to no good points. The story is just shit.. most of the characters are too. TBH i was a big fan of Oreimo and had a lot of expectations from this series and it turned out to be like this. I would not really recommend this series to anyone unless you are really big fan of moe.. but still i don't think you will like anyways. But hey.. at least its STEP sister this time.

Although, even when it does happen, there's still some slight confusion on my sidebecause I honestly think there's going to have to be a time skip. Why? Because a 12ish girl dating her not-blood-related-brother (emphasiize that part) would kind of seem wrong.

Anyways, the anime wasn't so disgusting like some reviewers have said. This is my first review I have ever written, and I wanted my first review to be about something special, so I chose Eromanga Sensei. It was the black sheep of 2017, and for good reasons. This show is trash, but I mean real trash. There are so many jokes that cross the line that people went insane, including me! I find this show incredibly trashy.... but as you guessed by my score I gave this anime, I also really, really liked it. My enjoyment was a absolute 10. Why, you may ask. Is it because I am a sick bastard or because this showmay actually be good? Well, let's take a look at Eromanga Sensei.  


Story: 7/10  

The story despite being the most controversial aspect of this show is the least interesting aspect. Masamune gets a new step-sister (called Sagiri), but she stays all day in her room. Izumi is also a Masamune writes light novels and works with the mysterious ''Eromanga Sensei'' who makes lewd erotica. ''Eromanga Sensei'' turns out to be Sagiri, which changes the relationship between Sagiri in more then one way  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°). Then story goes all over the place, from rivalry between Masamune and Elf to love triangles and sofort.  


The story is not really that special, besides that a 13-year old girl is in love with her brother who is 16. That part is also why a lot of people don't like this anime: It feels wrong. And it is also wrong, but I will get into later why this actually helps the anime. But overal, not a special story, but it does it job.  


Art: 8/10  

The animations are smooth and the drawings Sagiri draws look fantastic (NO NO NOT THAT WAY). The colors of the whole anime are laid-back. The art of this anime is not really that special, but it still looks good.  


Sound: 8/10  

The sound is not really anything worth talking about, but the OP and the ED are so good. Especially the ED. It is so lively and happy. It also reminds me a lot of ''Walking On Sunshine'' by Katrina & The Waves. Maybe that's why I like it so much.  


The Enjoyment: 10/10  

The first half of the anime I constantly screamed of disgust. It was trashy, it was disgusting, it didn't felt good. But you know what I also did throughout the whole anime?  


I laughed. Oh boy I laughed.  


This is, no joke, the funniest anime I have ever seen (besides the Ghost Stories dub). And the trash helpt with it. Because I screamed of disgust a lot, I became sensitive to my other emotions, which in this case lead me to laugh a lot. The selfaware humor mixed with the ridiculous and disgusting fanservice made for some memorable and hilarious scenes. After the first half, I didn't care about the trash anymore. All I did was laugh.  


Overal: 9/10  

I enjoyed my time with this anime more then I should.  


So the question is, do I recommend it?  


This is tough, because the biggest drawback of this anime is the trash (this does not aply to me). You will get disgusted. You will be shocked. But if you can look past all of that, you have a hilarious show. So I would recommend it if you can endure the trash.

[Spoiler Warning]
Another siscon work from the author that gave us OreImo, surely this one must be as good and hopefully with a satisfying ending.
Who knows? Because I don't see how anyone could in good faith call this a good anime and hate themselves so much to endure watching it to the end.
Let's knock off the easy things first; starting with:
Sound and music: To be honest there's nothing spectacular here, the OP/ED are quite nice however. 1/2 points.
Art and animation: The art is quite nice and the illustrations drawn by the characters are fairly gorgeous, however the animation is lackluster in certain episodes such as #6where 2 of the characters are shown moving to a new area through a series of stills as they continue their conversation, rather lazy coming from A-1 Pictures. And let's be honest, the age of consent in Japan might be 13, but sexualizing teenagers should not be praised. 1/2 points.\n\n
Story and Characters: Okay so what do we have here, brother living alone with his sister, classic siscon plot... but wait! They're not even blood related, how original indeed. Except it's really easy to figure out that this was an attempt to bypass the same publishing regulations that prevented the author from making a good ending to OreImo.\n\n
Let's continue that later, let's look at the characters. Generic big brother who writes light novels for a living, shut-in little sister that draws lewd art, tsundere love interest that's the MC's rival, overly energetic and happy school girl that loves dicks... WAIT WHAT?!\n
Yes you read that right, in the start of episode 2 we're properly introduced to Megumi, the little sister's class mate (or would be if she actually went to school instead of being a shut-in). And she insists that she not only loves dicks, but that every girl her age loves them! This being said with a smile while uncomfortably invading the MC's personal space and staring at his crotch, only to be played off as a joke?! Okay let's be real here, you're a 13 year old schoolgirl, you come to a stranger's home, you ring their doorbell and then proclaim with a big smile right in their face that you love dicks. I'm sorry but, are you an underage prostitute? What in the name of all that is holy is wrong with you? This isn't something you say as a joke even to your best friend of several years, let alone a complete stranger. Even the MC himself asks "What's happened to Japan?" upon hearing this, and let me tell you it's nothing good. This scene alone should've made me (and everyone else) stop watching and drop the show for good, but I was foolish enough to give it a second chance.\n\n
This foolish behavior lasted until episode 6 where the MC signs up for a rookie tournament in order to secure a publishing opportunity for his upcoming novel. But oh no, a new rival appears and she's going to stop him from attaining this spot... for some reason. Said rival is the highly praised author Masamune who's produced a bestseller spanning 11 volumes and a 2 season anime adaption. Except that due to her status as a bestselling author she has no problems securing publishing opportunities for her work meaning she has no motive for entering this tournament, the tournament is also strictly for no-name rookies (the MC only being allowed in due to his editor pulling some strings), something she definitely isn't. Is this the kind of writing that passes for a plot these days? Normally I'd give both of these categories a point each but due to these 2 outrageous insults to human intelligence and societal norms I'm going to deduct a point each, leaving them: 0/4 points\n\n
And finally, did I enjoy this show? To be honest, what IS there to enjoy? The bad plot? The sexualized underaged characters? I imagine the only reason people watch this is because of the latter as they're somehow incapable of just watching a loli hentai instead, something that deserves a sudden visit from the authorities. Don't get me wrong, I like cute girls, I like lewd stuff, but this show should not be allowed to air on TV, I don't ever recall feeling disgusted from watching an anime. Admittedly I somehow endured watching it halfway through so I guess that's worth a bonus point for masochistic pleasure. 1/2 points.\n\n
And now with some advanced math we total that up to an amazing: 3/10, the worst score I've ever given. Do humanity a favor and go watch something that isn't hebephilia.

I like it and all but leaves with a cliff hangar which to me is kinda stupid. I want to know what happens next make it like naruto but it doesn't have to be as long as naruto . "Sister, I have something to tell you that's been in my mind for a while, I love you, not as a sister but as a woman! I loved you from the first moments I saw you getting carried in mother's arms, I loved the way you smile, I loved you so much that I always hide in your closet so I can smell all your clothes, each has your beautiful scent!" "Bro, what the f***?"
Well, if that doesn't convince your sisters to love you, neither will this anime. Eromanga-sensei is an anime about a young boy named Masamune who is an aspiring author, writing lightnovels to provide for him and his sister named Sagiri who is secretly an illustrator for several light novels including Masamune's work, however most of her prized illustrations are lewd girls. Yes, smell that plot real good.


The story is not half bad, but it's not that good either, to put it simply, it's an upgrade of OreImo. To put it in detail, it's surprisingly a bit in depth than from what it's supposed to portray. From the several perspectives of the anime community, it's the same as OreImo, 'a siscon falling in love with his sister', but most of them didn't take into account was the story of them writing and drawing for their books, which was a good storyline of its own. Yes, that's right, it's not just about making a harem and then reject them all for your little sister. (even though it was kinda....portrayed like that.)


Yes, music is subjective to every ears, but even I, who am not much of a fan for songs so generic such as Eromanga-sensei's Opening and Ending theme, seemed to enjoy it even just a bit, it's cheerful, upbeat and colorful. It's to prepare your eyes and souls getting destroyed before an episode starts.


The art is drawn to be quite polished and with vibrant colors, much likely expected for a slice of life at this age, I would say it's average compared to the competitors of the genre, though it was pleasing to my eyes. The animation is quite mundane to say the least, which was also expected from a slice of life romantic comedy, it wasn't anything special since they exaggerated facial expressions and body languages, this might have been fitting a few years back, but after seeing anime within this genre that uses realistic facial expressions and body languages, Eromanga-sensei looked as it was outdated in terms of visual capabilities. But you're here to watch a big brother and a little sister getting nervous with each other in more ways than one, so I can see you don't really care, weirdos.


Every existing characters are just the 'heroines' of Masamune, as expected, however, they were at least much more interesting than I had thought initially. Muramasa who was also a light novel author, with a slight elegant appearance, and by that I mean she wears a kimono most of the time. Yamada, a playful light novel author who procrastinate a lot but is considered a prodigy at writing, to be frank, she might be the most memorable character throughout the anime, probably due to her personality. (and she's nuts) Finally, Shidou, who might be homophobic and was misled to believe that Masamune is homosexual. Everyone were a part of the anime, and not one of them lacked anything since they were introduced, as Masamune's slaves.


In short, I personally enjoyed Eromanga-sensei but I do not highly regard it as an anime, it was filled with cliches, dumb cringe-worthy moments, plots that contradicted itself and a premise that makes me want to kill myself. Despite all of that, I enjoyed it for being itself, a romantic comedy shitpost, and with that I say, Anime is trash and so are we!


I swear if they don't make a season 2 or at least a special episode where they realised fully that they both love each other and go on a date, I will....uh..... forget about I guess...

This series is some of the most exquisite otaku trash I have ever feasted upon, managing to reach so high by stooping so low. We've got panty shots, we've got 'not actually related by blood' incest escapism, we've got love triangles involving an average at best lead male character, we've got obnoxious stereotypes in a show that thinks its meta by having the characters point it out, we've got 12 year old girls proclaiming their love for some good old 'o chin-chin', we've got tasteless gay jokes, we've got awkward plot conveniences, and a random tournament ark. 
Eromanga Sensei is a masterpiece of it's genre,mainly because it knows what it is and never tries to hide it. There's no shielding yourself from the fact that you are watching lowest common denominator trash, you know it, I know it, the creators and animators know it. There's no 'I watch it for the plot' shield because the plot is trash, there's no 'I watch it for the characters' shield because the characters are trash, and there's no 'I watch it because Best Girl' shield because every Best Girl  is in reality the Worst Girl.


It's a buffet of any and every cheap cliche found in pandering otaku bait cranked to 11. It was crude, immature, and lazy, I loved every second of it. It is a perfect trash fire that we can only experience once a generation, where its lowest qualities actually come together to create its best quality. It's like drinking Mad Dog from a wine glass, or eating gas station roller grill food on fine china.

***NO SPOILERS HERE***
Eromanga-sensei  definitely deserves more love. While not an absolutely incredible anime or unique concept, it is quite entertaining - in quite some time, since I watched SAO, I found myself waiting eagerly for a new episode, even when I couldn't explain exactly why I like it so much.
I'll separate this in parts:
Story (7/10) - Many people complain about this anime merely because of the theme (incest? even though it's not really incestuous?) however I find the story very charming. I have some criticism on some areas though - like many harems, all the characters are inexplicably attracted to the protagonist, which hasno outstanding personality (i.e. the script writing makes it seem that Masamune blinds himself to avoid situations, in an attempt to create comical relief, but weakening the chances of anybody bonding with the character in the process).


Art (8/10) - The art is pretty good. For an anime about artists and story-writers, it does it's job very well. It's not outstanding - but it's very good. I'm not an art specialist in any way, but the anime's artstyle was easy and appealing for my eyes.


Sound (9/10) - I loved the intro song, and I have no complaints about the sound. There isn't much to talk about this one.


Character (7/10) - As I stated in Story, the main character is retarded, which is common for harems. The contrast of the personalities between the three main female characters (Sagiri, Elf and Muramasa) makes up much about the protagonist's flaws, and allows the viewer to bond with them. 

Side note: Why are the Oreimo characters listed in this anime when they appear for 5 seconds? lul


Enjoyment (10/10) - I'm a little bit biased in this one. This is my favorite genre, and I had a lot of fun watching Eromanga-sensei. I recommend it to everybody reading this review, it's worth your while.

By this point, so much has been said about this series that it's hard to tell what to actually think. Is it merely a raunchy comedy series that accidentally attracted a larger audience than intended? Or is it something far worse? To phrase the question simply, is Eromanga-sensei really that bad?
...Yes.
Eromanga-sensei is an anime that is broken to its very core. Its first issue is the most basic issue any show can have: the premise is bad. It attempts (poorly) to tell the story of Masamune Izumi, a successful teenage light novel author with a remarkable ability for causing sexy things to inexplicably happen aroundhim. Joining him in his lascivious endeavors is his loli sister Sagiri, a child who makes a living drawing porn (something something FBI…). Incidentally, she also happens to draw the illustrations for Masamune’s novels; although, through a contrivance of cosmic proportions, he remains unaware of this fact… even though they live in the same house.


The sheer poorness of this premise is frankly staggering.


To begin with, it lifts the aspiring light novel author plot directly out of Oreimo’s first season. I was no fan of the idea there, and certainly am no fan of it here. The notion that the fifteen-year-old Kirino could get a light novel published with such ease always struck me as a bizarre deviation from the relatively grounded nature of Oreimo's first season up to that point, and it strikes me as far worse in Eromanga-sensei, where the characters are all several years younger.


To make matters worse, the fact that Masamune has somehow remained unknowing of his sister’s profession despite her living in the same house as him is downright asinine. It’s bad enough that I have to believe that an unremarkable teenager could get a series of successful novels published, but now I’m also supposed to accept that his kawaii imouto does the illustrations and he never suspected a thing? No thanks—I don’t buy it.


I should mention that my intention here is not to suggest that realism is particularly important in anime; rather, I expect a slice of life series about otaku culture to have some grounding in the reality of otaku culture. Otherwise, what’s the point? There’s simply no reason for the show to even incorporate elements of a real phenomenon like otaku culture if it only plans to skew them beyond recognition anyway. For all of its shortcomings, this was something that Oreimo did well. It painted a pretty shady picture of otaku culture, but (excluding the light novel section) it showed characters interacting with this culture in a very real and relatable way. They formed communities of fans, attended events, and even had heated discussions about their favorite anime. It was played comically, but there was a definite sense that these events came from a place of experience and passion for the world of otaku on the part of the author. None of this is the case in Eromanga-sensei. The characters of this show live in a distant fantasy world where teenagers write light novels and children create hentai. Being an otaku here means nothing more than enjoying lewd light novels with lewder drawings. This is not the reality of otaku culture—not to most people, at any rate—and the show gains nothing from portraying it in this way.


From what I’ve written about its premise alone, you’re probably expecting me to write an almighty diatribe against the rest of Eromanga-sensei, but actually, past its premise the show is barely worth discussing. Things progress exactly how anyone would expect them to. More unremarkable characters are introduced, more absurd situations occur, and the show settles into a routine of raunchy mediocrity punctuated only by the occasional scene offensive enough to warrant a reaction. I honestly think the show would have been forgotten almost immediately, lost in a slew of other sexual anime comedies, if not for these extra offensive moments. Thanks, however, to delightful scenes like the one where a twelve-year-old girl says “I love dicks—all girls my age do,” this show began an unfortunate ascension to the status of a meme. The good old anime memesters began crawling out of the woodwork, and eventually big figures in the community like Gigguk started paying the series some attention. Now, I love Gigguk’s videos about Eromanga-sensei as much as any other self-respecting weeb, but I do suspect that without them and the related memes, this series would have been quickly sentenced to a well-deserved eternity of obscurity.


I bring this up because this meme-ability represents my other main problem with this series: it tries too hard to be offensive. This is speculation upon my part, but I believe that Eromanga-sensei’s writer knew that his brand of imouto-themed otaku comedies had waning relevance, so he deliberately used these shocking moments as a last ditch effort at increasing publicity for his work. And… I guess it worked. These moments became memes and the memes became a form of free marketing for the show. I would call it ingenious if it didn’t cause me and countless other hapless weebs to waste five hours of our time watching a terrible anime. To clarify, none of this is to say that I have any inherent problem with Eromanga-sensei’s nature as a offensive show. Being bawdy is an excellent and time-honored way of approaching humor, and Eromanga-sensei… sometimes does it well. The dick-lover scene is bad, but it’s bad not because there is any inherent problem with twelve-year-olds who love dicks; rather, it fails because it does nothing particularly humorous with this idea. This is the core of the problem: instead of using offensive elements as a means to create humor, these elements are played as though they are intrinsically humorous.


What seems oddest about this situation is that the writer occasionally uses bawdy elements to make actual jokes, so it’s clear that he understands how to do this, he just fails to do it most of the time. For instance, compare the dick-lover scene to a later scene in episode twelve where Sagiri tries to draw some good ole hentai but can’t seem to correctly identify the location of the male genitals. This scene is also rather lewd, but it’s much funnier than the dick-lover scene because it manages to go beyond being superficially raunchy and makes a real joke (namely that Sagiri pretends to be experienced about sex but is really laughably naïve). Being the sort of tasteless person I am, I think I would have earnestly enjoyed this series if it were able to keep to the obscene-but-funny standard set by this last scene. Instead, however, Eromanga-sensei’s humor falls as flat as its premise, leaving us with a series that is worthless from almost any viewpoint—a series, in other words, that is not only trashy but trash as well.


Note: I used the phrase "dick-lover scene" three times in this review without even meaning to. I feel like that says something about the kind of anime Eromanga-sensei is...

Final Thoughts: This anime is a true garbage pile with no reason for people to watch. Nothing about this show is stand out or is interesting. I would say pass this show if you're looking for a show that is intriguing or fun. If you're looking for a show with awful writing that will make you feel uncomfortable then this is the show for you.
Story: The story is literally OreImo but worse. Which makes a lot of sense considering they are from the same author. This story is nothing but incest and pedophilia which only made me feel uncomfortable and disgusted with myself from watchingthis. The writing is cliche and uncomfortable giving us a lot of moments to joke about how the writing is awful.


Art and sound: The art and animation was pretty solid coming from A-1 pictures. Though the character designs are pretty generic I like the presentation. The animation was good, but not stand out. The music was forgettable with not many stand out pieces except for the fun OP. The voice actors did a okay job at playing the characters,but nothing outstanding.



Characters: The cast is nothing but cliches we've seen before in other better shows. The shy tsundere little sister, chuunibyou that thinks she's a princess, calm and collected girl, and the dense main lead. The worst part is the other two girls in this ''romantic'' plot are much better then the little sister who literally sexually harasses other people. All characters are genuinely annoying with no real reason to like or root for the cast. 

 watched this show to simply understand what the buzz was all about, and now I know this show is garbage with nothing to make it different or interesting from other bad ecchi shows.

I’m not sure how anyone would react when if they ever found out their little sister is a famous artist in the light novel industry but has the penname “eromanga sensei”. This is the story of the step-siblings Sagiri Izumi and Masamune Izumi who are a light novel duo with Sagiri being the artist and Masamune being the writer. It should be noted that the siblings are in love with each other so its basically Oreimo version 2 but this time its legal since they’re not blood related so that means they can get married.
The anime starts out with the 2 siblings living alone ayear after their parents died. Due to the loss, Sagiri refuses to go to school much less come out of her room and Masamune understands what she’s going through ever since he lost his 1st mom, so he takes care of her by doing the cooking, laundry, and other chores. He doesn’t force her to go to school and all he really wants is for her to go out of her room so he can see her face. Masamune is just a high school student but he is also a semi-famous light novel author that just finished his debut series. The high school kid is the one who brings the bacon.


It didn’t take him long to find out that his NEET little sister is also the one who does the ecchi illustrations for his light novel. Chaos ensues and some ecchi remarks were said but the two managed to come to an understanding. While Masamune-sensei tries to create his 2nd publicized series he encounters a more prominent author that becomes an obstacle to his works and later on another author who’s even more famous that tries to destroy his dreams.


While it may seem like its about Masamune-sensei’s journey to fame as a light novel author, the anime is actually about how he can have a normal relationship with his sister. Masamune is a good brother, he does what he can to support his sister’s current lifestyle, and is just happy to see her smiling genuinely like when she’s streaming her drawings to her pervy fans. Though he confesses to her that he is genuinely in love with her, he follows up by saying that he wants to be her brother most of all and is just satisfied with that.


Speaking of confessions, this romantic comedy shake things up a bit with nearly all of the harem characters confessing to the MC at different points in the anime with one of the confessions being incredibly romantic and actually heavier than a normal confession. The anime is also very perverse with the imouto actually acting like a pervy old man and living up to her penname of eromanga sensei. There was even a character who’s only in middle school, just openly say she loves dicks. I gotta give props though to the level of detail the pantsus have with one of them even having that tag you see in the back with details like size or material used.


It was also nice to see that there was no problem with copyright issues where we can actually some real titles of light novels like Toradora, Sword Art Online, Shakugan no Shana, and many more. This was probably only the 2nd anime I’ve personally seen that does that (the 1st to my memory is Bakuman). This anime is also probably the closest one that portrays the light novel industry though very lightly. The other ones that portray the industry are Bakuman for manga, Shirobako for anime, New Game! for video game development, and Sore ga Seiyuu! for Voice Acting.


I was also shocked that it took me 11 episodes to realize that the author and illustrator of the source material are the very same ones of Oreimo. It was also great seeing the Oreimo cast make cameo appearances including the Gokou sisters. While I did enjoy Eromanga Sensei, it felt lacking when compared to how I enjoyed Oreimo but it was still enjoyable in and of itself.


Eromanga Sensei is a solid anime that’s good just to have some laughs and chill out. I actually found it quite enjoyable. It was pretty good seeing Sagiri slowly coming out of her shell and go out of her comfort zone (her room) and even try to make friends with others. Her transformation to becoming a normal person is a sight to see throughout the anime, though sometimes its out of jealousy for the other girls that interact with her brother and they even had a great backstory episode that really fleshes out the siblings before they became siblings.


P.S. You can also read my review here and video game reviews if you're interested

Eromanga is an anime in which it takes all the well developed characters and has the protagonist shut down all of the well developed characters for a younger step sister who has almost no redeeming qualities, it starts off as a great anime with a path unclear leaving a curiosity for the user and hooks them for a couple more episodes it then introduces some other girls one which is a better author than the protagonist, this adds an interesting character which is developed just to be shut down, there is someone who is in love with the protagonists work and does everything she canto try to win him over just to get shut down as well because of his odd love with his step sister because "incest is wincest", it is petty that what started as a potentially good anime got instantly shut down, once reaching episode 9 i decided to give up on this anime because after the most developed character getting shut down for some weird selfish sister with no redeeming qualities because "plot" it ruins an anime which could have been a good romance, what should have just been a guy finding out his sisters secret (something that happened in oreimo) and then has him reject good characters for a boring plain character which is the "waifu" because reasons (something else that happened in oreimo) and even has a oreimo cameo, overall it feels more of a show with terrible writing and plot which was made to leech off of the disappointment from oreimos ending.

I love this because I'm trying to write light novels in Japanese myself and can relate to the genre and main character. I think it's so cool that at a young age he was able to write novels, his sister draw illustrations, and meet strict deadlines.
Also the fact that they lived under the same roof but didn't know that they were working together is really funny and creative. 
There have been a lot of negative reviews on this, but they were probably all written by people who have no appreciation for this sort of humor and how hard it is to write light novels, overcominghikikomori tendencies, and deep appreciation of the otaku culture. (really boring people tbh)


First off--this was written by the same person (tsukasa fushimi )who made Ore no imouto ga konna ni kawaii wake ga nai...so you have to understand the genre to appreciate it, living with a sister who likes ero stuff, and having an awkward relationship.The brother in this is more similar-minded (likes otaku culture from the start) and the sister is shy but still has tsundere attributes. 


A lot of people complained that a 12 year old was joking about chinchin and probably most people who reviewed this dropped it at the 2nd episode...

Even 5 year olds will say the word chinchin to joke around in Japan, so what if the author made a 12 year old say that she likes chinchin. It's nothing to get offended about. I've personally met 12 year olds that were doing it when I was in middle school...and it's true for Japan too.. I'm sure it was just a joke though. 

There are similar jokes in ore no imouto as well (maybe slightly different but indeed shimoneta (sexual joke) 

It fits with the genre, the characters are working on ero stuff...it wouldn't make sense for them to all be boring and never use shimoneta. 


I would recommend this to anyone who likes awkward but funny situations, young brilliant people (I think they are pretty amazing to get famous at their age),likes hikikomori, wants to understand Japanese shimoneta more or otaku culture.wants to see some more slice of life elements than say a fighting anime or something in a fantasy world.

I wouldn't recommend this to those who watch anime very casually or do not get a kick out of this kind of genre/dislikes shimoneta. I especially wouldn't recommend this to children because of the type of jokes and ero-based story.
