Before I say anything vaguely substantive, I feel that the three most appropriate words to summarize this show are “tasteless,” “incest,” and “cancer,” so here are the lyrics to “Tasteless Incest” by Cancer.
Old man, sick in the head
Daughter's children on his bed
Twisted ways rule his life
Forging deceit, bred to lie
From the decades he has lived
He's never stopped, where it begins
Rapes his family when they are young
Hoping they would carry on
Keeping in the family
Human disgrace
The younger one's first
He thinks nobody minds
Tasteless incest
Senseless lust
Satisfaction, sickening trust
Led to believe that it's alright
Young boy cries into the night
He will never change his way
When he's dead, he may repay
Hateis burning in young eyes\n
When they're older, evil will rise\n\n
I am confident that this ranks among the worst media I have ever consumed in any format.  The stuffiest fustian of verbose Victorian vapidity I trudged through in high school pressed less distressingly on my attention span.  The most deranged demonstration of depravity and the most grotesque glorification of gore unstomached by Takashi Miike would feel less inimical to my sense of basic human decency.  The most flagrantly fetid farce of a one-man basement black metal demo exudes more respect for its medium and a more professional grasp of its own capabilities.  No first-year art student on a deconstructive Dadaist bender could alchemically assemble something so calculated and hateful in its diametrical opposition to the very concept of artistic quality.  Had Caligula, Gilles de Rais, and Albert Fish spent a weekend torturing their way through the red light districts of Sodom and then hired Zhu Yu and Eli Roth to document their exploits with a soundtrack from GG Allin, the resulting film would have been less overt in its moral repugnance than Eromanga Sensei.\n\n
From the studio that muddled through Sword Art Online and the author who inexplicably kept paper and pen together long enough to write Oreimo comes an abominable affair of misery, woe, incest, sexual misconduct, and insulting levels of inanity and incompetence.  This is a pathetic and pedophilic tragedy, an akratic assault on thousands of years of ethical development, the medium of animation, and the intellect, conscience, and aesthetic sensibilities of any viewer possessing the mental capacity to open up Crunchyroll and run a search for “Eromanga Sensei.”  Talents such as Yui Ishikawa and ClariS were wasted on this show as a Stradivarius would be wasted on Kotomi Ichinose; talents never showed up to fill most of the other important roles.  Aside from that catchy OP and the solid ED, there is nothing redeeming about this show.  Not one clever bit of directing, not one unexpected gag that lands, not one moving swell of emotion; even the fan service is completely incompetent, and thank goodness for that.\n\n
Forced memes, forced drama, forced humor, and characters forced into uncomfortable encounters of a sexual nature (either by the script or by each other).  A setting completely devoid of respect for the physical constraints that surround productivity in writing, publishing, and selling.  Supposedly god-tier erotic art that bears more resemblance to perfectly average light novel insert pages.  Shallow characters, shallow conflicts, shallow backgrounds, and shallow...  themes?  Are there any?  Hollow and glib misrepresentations of the life of a hikikomori so off the mark that the premise gets bungled before you can say, “This looks like trauma-induced agoraphobia and she should probably see a doctor.”  A protagonist so milquetoast and devoid of personality that he makes the standard harem anime hero look like the singular and nuanced love child of Charles Foster Kane and Motoko Kusanagi.  Relationships so unhealthy, manipulative, and downright abusive that 50 Shades of Grey looks like the world's greatest G-rated romantic comedy by comparison.  This show is a cesspit of anime tropes reduced to their basest, least interesting, and most offensive levels.\n\n
You may think that you have seen enough anime to understand what Eromanga Sensei is doing; after all, the harem structure, brother/sister complex, and the sexualization of underage characters are hardly uncharted territory for anime.  Frankly, the most standard and innocuous elements of Eromanga Sensei are already in themselves lazy tropes that we shouldn't have to tolerate in our entertainment, but the things that this show does it does almost exclusively worse than anyone else.  The way these characters act is only ever monumentally stupid or completely inappropriate for normal, functioning humans or both.\n\n
I close by recalling the immortal interjection with which T.E. Lawrence opened The Mint:\n\n
“God, this is awful.”\n

You know those kind of animes where the quality of the anime is directly proportional to the screentime that one character gets?
yeah me too
Anyways, Eromanga Sensei is that kind of anime. It has its moments, but I just thought of it as another Oreimo with an illegal loli as the main "love" interest.
Story: Story? There wasn't much. I mean, it did try to focus on Masamune improving his relationship with his shut-in sister, but he accomplished that pretty quickly. After that, he was trying to create novels that would do well. Storywise, Eromanga Sensei is basic, with enough plot to pass as a normal SoLanime.


Art: The art in Eromanga Sensei is alright. Nothing really stuck out to me, except maybe the lewd scenes. Those always stick out, though. The animation in this anime is a bit choppy at some points, but I've been through worse. However, I did enjoy the animation during the "camp" part. And speaking of that part, it's also the best part in the anime, and the part with the least amount of screentime from Sagiri! Such a coincidence!


Sound: The voice acting in this anime is actually one of the better parts of the anime. The voice actors did a nice job, in my opinion, of bringing out the "characters". I'll explain why that's in quotes later. Other than the VA, the opening and ending fits the anime well. The ending fits especially, since the upbeat song fits nicely with the mood and style of Eromanga Sensei.


Character: The characters in this anime are kind of shallow. Masamune just comes out to be another Kyousuke, with the added element of him being an author. Sagiri, on the other hand, really doesn't have much character aside from the shy younger sister who draws lewd art better than I ever could, and is a bit of a closet pervert. The only person that I felt was a good character was best girl Elf. Just don't say I'm picking favourites.


Enjoyment: Although underwhelming in half the categories that I described, I still enjoyed this throughout the 12 episode series. It's slightly stupid, which my "fun" side enjoys, and has its moments where it deals with completely different topics, as seen in the camp episodes when Elf and Masamune have a moment together. So, in my opinion, Eromanga Sensei wasn't particularly great, but it also wasn't bad. If you can watch an anime more for the jokes and randomness, but also are fine with a slight bit of romance in the middle (particularly with Masamune x Elf), I'd say that you could go for it. 


(edit: animation probably smooth, but my wifi sucks)

I have no moral gripe with this series, i'd like to get that out of the way. A series can still flourish with all sorts of controversy such as Loli and Incest, Monogatari is one of my favorite shows. But this show is completely filled with abhorrent (((QUALITY))) animation, cringy reused tropes, episodes with no plot progression, lazy writing and more. One of my major problems with it is that the fan service scenarios are so unbelievable that it breaks your immersion. This could be solved if it were a self aware comedy but the most humor you'll get out of these scenarios is "xdshe isnt wearing panties". Almost every girl in the series that loves Masamune (almost all of them) has nearly no reason to and makes every confession look out of place and forced. I have watched my fair share of Harem and Ecchi but this series laughs at their attempts to create unjustified love for the main character. The fanservice in this series isn't limited to sexual imagery, the fan service comes in the form of watching Mary Sue 12 year old billionaires fall in love with the main character for NO reason so the watcher can project their pathetic life onto the main character and feel that one day it may happen to them. My MAL rating of a 4 is almost completely based on my enjoyment due to the cringe and shock of watching this series. This series is terrible but I would still watch it again just to see how trash a story can become. The only redeemable quality besides that is the studio's ability to put in Screenshottable and Gifable moments into the series. If I was judging this series based on that it would probably be the best one i've ever seen. Their voice acting was also pretty decent and the OP/ED were well done. If you've read this far, thanks for reading the ramblings of some teenager on the internet.

Good 7, sound:

Fair 6, Character:


I basically have some mixed emotions about the character personalities, around here, cu'z of the fact that the main characters themselves were pretty much a complicated double standard , Like Masamune, whom we can't tell if he has some siscon with Sagiri or just being a caring brother, the point is that he takes care of Sagiri as if he is spoiler her like a queen and yet he makes no attempts to get him out of the outside world.....as if he is encouraging that Sagiri stay's that way, also he keeps denying that he has no siscon.......to say the least, but he also makes no attempts, to get into a relationship neither with Elf or with Muramasa for that matter. Now Sagiri is also a complicated character at one point she disses her brother for thinking that he has some lewd thoughts about her, but she seems to like it anyways, also how the two came to be as step siblings was not disclose, we can't tell if both parents of both parties were still living or is only one of them still around. Now about the other girls like Elf, Muramasa, Megumi and Tomoe, they were pretty straight forward and I like that, but, alas, we probably would never see any relationship develop outside of Masamune X Sagiri arc.

IMAO, they should have just ended at episode 11, since the 12 episode was a bummer, the only consolation was seeing Elf and Muramasa in their bikini bodies.


Poor 3, Overall:


It does have a funny side to say the least, but it still was a bit annoying when them Aniplex guys can't seem to go much with the fanservices , so at one point you may laugh , but it get's dampen with the last episode, so I hope they don't think about making another season.

Edited 6/24/17 after seeing Ep. 12
The reason I'm picking this seemingly generic anime as my first review is because it generates exceeding amounts of controversy and controversy is fun. Most reviews of this show lie within the binary of "literally the worst garbage I've ever seen" and "pretty good because cute girls" and most of the remaining reviews cite moral arguments against the ages of the characters. While none of these opinions are blatantly wrong, there is merit in sometimes having middling opinions so that not every anime discussion devolves into a SAO war, AoT war, or US presidential election. 
So what is this middlingopinion I have on Eromanga-sensei? It sucks. By "sucks" I don't mean the kind of suck that generic self-insert self-validation fantasy LN adaptations bring to the table, instead it comes close to being downright terrible. Yet I found enough enjoyment in this anime to marathon it and not for the expected reason of laughing at a trainwreck. There was something genuinely enjoyable about this show but I'll get to that later. As for the


Story (2/10):


, the most noticeable problem with it is that everything about it is so mind-bogglingly contrived that it's just not possible to achieve the suspension of disbelief needed to self-insert as the generic male LN protagonist. Though I have to credit them slightly for making the protagonist earn his position by having him be a workaholic instead of some underappreciated genius with overpowered abilities, it's his surroundings that are messed up. The MC's 12 year old adoptive sister Sagiri happens to be a professional-level artist who he happened to meet over the Internet a few years prior and she happened to like his stories despite no connections back then, both of their sets of parents happened to die near the same time, she happens to be a NEET who finds the act of walking inside her own house debilitating, she also happens to be incredibly lewd for her age. And that's just the contrivances for one character. Other characters include a girl who happens to be living next door after finding out they are rivals and a girl who happens to obsessively love the MC's writing despite being incredibly successful. 


All of these contrivances exist to create the "ideal" OTP imouto character and to throw in a harem at the same time, but these ideas cannot coexist and trying to find the best of both worlds will lead to inevitable failure, a mistake made by the trainwreck that is Oreimo S2. A-1 Pictures clearly did not learn their lesson as Eromanga-sensei fails in a similar fashion. An example of Eromanga butchering its writing to rake in the easy harem bucks while keeping the main couple intact is the beach arc. The arc itself is awful in the first place and shouldn't exist; nothing gets done and the fanservice is somehow *lacking* compared to the rest of the show despite beach episodes being a prime opportunity to show half naked girls. But the main problem is the inconsistency in Sagiri's character in order to make this arc even happen. Why the hell would a bossy, possessive, and needy girl like Sagiri be okay and even excited with the brother she's madly in love with being taken by two chicks he wants to bone to the wet, steamy island of Letsfuckallnight? The anime makes a lamebrained excuse of a bribe or some shit but it's still incredibly out of character. Other excuses to maintain the harem include Sagiri refusing to confess when the MC repeatedly tells her he loves her romantically (a rare occurrence in these things) and the MC being the usual LN/harem dimwit when it comes to romance and ignoring obvious hints. By the end of episode 4 you will probably be mildly to incredibly pissed off and find yourself telling them to just fuck already.


Speaking of LNs, I find it bothersome that Eromanga-sensei pats itself in the back by following every LN trend and referencing other LNs while there are no attempts to subvert tropes, create self-deprecating jokes, or have the characters discuss ways to improve the medium in a meaningful way despite the series being about writing LNs. But let's be honest, this series isn't about writing LNs so much as it is about wanting to bone your sister, so it's time to move on to the fanservice.


If you read my name, it's clear that this show is so deep in my strike zone that I'd need a blindfold to not hit a home run. Unfortunately, Eromanga-sensei is at least one and a half eyepatches and my bat is more like a melted popsicle. While Sagiri posing at various angles to draw her own lewd pictures at different perspective makes sense, just about everything else doesn't. Shots of Sagiri's wiggling ass during scenes of normal conversation throw the entire mood off for the viewer. Why does Sagiri want to take pantyshots of literally every girl she meets when there are plenty of generic pantyshots online? Why does she put on her swimsuit in an unrelated episode and not the beach episode when she's clearly been shown to follow the yukata costumes during that event? And while I said I'd avoid moralfagging, why is there naked fanservice of Sagiri in an elementary school flashback? I say this because episode 11 in its entirety was a mess; it hypes the viewer up for Akihabara then spends 15 minutes laboriously detailing their past circumstance with a story that could have been explained in 5. 


Finally, while I admit to chuckling about once or twice per episode, it isn't particularly funny for something with Comedy in its genres. Then again, nearly everything has Comedy thrown in its genres for some reason so it gets a pass. Also the repetition of the same joke (door slamming in MC's face, Sagiri saying she doesn't know anyone named Eromanga-sensei) is done shamelessly and with no variation so seeing them in the later episodes was irritating.


EDIT: All those things said, it seems like they spent half the budget in the final episode; despite it being entirely a fanservice slice of life episode where Sagiri gets exposed to hentai and turns into a full-on perv, it had nearly all the comedic moments of the show that were actually funny. There was even a bit more character development for Sagiri in a few ways. Though there's no conclusive ending which will piss off shippers, it probably means a second season, whether that's a good thing or not. But this is exactly the kind of finale this season needed after unnecessary melodrama in the last ep.


By this point I've continuously been bitching about the flaws of Eromanga-sensei despite promising a middling review so where are the good points? In the Art and Character sections.


Art (7/10):


While there are noticeable budget cuts with still/cheap frames being scattered throughout the show, it does a decent job keeping itself looking consistent with its cutesy Oreimo style. The main selling point of this series is its character design, with female characters who are visually memorable and outfits which look great and are consistent with the (lack of) character each of these girls have. 


Sound (6/10):


No real flaws, forgettable ED, great decision in getting ClariS back from Oreimo because the OP is pretty damn catchy.


Characters (4/10):


An easy comparison for these characters is the cast of Oreimo, since the premise and structure are so similar. And to put it lightly, every character is noticeably worse than their Oreimo counterpart. That said, I'm still giving this show's characters a higher rating than Oreimo's because Kirino is the shittiest, most nightmarish cunt ever devised in any medium and Sagiri is just kind of boring.


Before the mob kills me, let me explain. Sagiri along with her previously mentioned contrivances is a mashup of every trait a lolicon would find cute that goes nowhere because she has her NEET status to fall back on. It's like adding lobster and caviar to tomato soup; it doesn't change anything because the base of tomato paste is overpowering. Her NEET status is used as an excuse to make her shy and her shyness is used as an excuse to keep the plot moving like a go-kart on a highway. The start of the series is noticeably slow because nothing meaningful happens in MC-Sagiri interactions, only ass shots and the occasional tsundere slap. She is admittedly the *one* character who gets character development in slowly growing out of her shut-in phase, though the reason for her being a shut-in (parents' death) and how it traumatizes her is never explored and she seems to get along fine in that regard. The only motivation she seems to have for anything is the MC's dick.


Masamune, the MC, isn't any better. His best selling point is that he puts in the damn work to make his dreams a reality unlike the many trailer trash LN protags who are overpowered prodigies. Besides that, he's the generic bumbling idiot when it comes to girls, he has no likable traits other than being a hard worker, and there is a distinct lack of development or internal monologue when he himself presents the moral dilemma of wanting to bang his little sister, but needing to act as an adult figure. Instead he seems to instantly shift gears with no acknowledgement from the story that this problem even exists.


Senju is Kuroneko minus everything that made Kuroneko good. She tries to clone the "shy badass" appeal but the badass part rarely comes out and at all the wrong times. Her (second) confession to Masamune is not only pointless, but the exact opposite of badass because wanting to quit writing after accomplishing her goal is both weak and stupid. There is also zero explanation of her writing style besides "wow shes rly good lol" when there are bandages on her hand and her whole backstory is about seeing Masamune's writing and being so inspired by it that she wrote her own stuff. Huge missed opportunity there.


Megumi was one of two characters (three counting the MC's boss) who actually moved the story along, and while she was characterized as an annoying normie at first, she started to get engrossed in LNs and had a budding relationship with Sagiri that was potentially interesting. And then she vanished from the story entirely because harem! She could've actually gone somewhere and yet Eromanga-sensei refuses because it can't write character development for shit.


Shidou is a walking gay joke and the librarian girl is cute and obsessed with LNs. Not much else to say about them.


Elf is said to be the most inconsistent character in this series. Yet this inconsistency is the show's saving grace, as she is one of very few things that actually get the story moving in some meaningful direction. The inconsistencies aren't even annoying like Sagiri's because real people are not coherent characters in nature. They can be immature brats in one second and wise in the next; they can be lazy and fun-seeking while simultaneously wanting to be productive. These are all characteristics of Elf and they all fit in the persona of a hyperactive, hormonal teenager. The characteristics are all used to their best extent (relative to what Eromanga-sensei can manage) to create someone who I would realistically want to hang out with if I can look past her air of childish overconfidence. It's no wonder that Masamune ditched his dick's wet dream so he could crack open a cold one with Elf and chill for long enough that it got the plot ball moving. Eromanga-sensei managed to write *one* character who is both beneficial to the plot and has a cute personality that isn't just "tappable loli ass", a rare feat for the show. That's why Elf is least bad girl. (I'd say best girl but that's an honor for shows that are at least decent..)


Enjoyment (5/10):


Holy shit this is getting long. Start was slow and boring. Picked up in the middle then got boring again. Then got even more boring after the story promised otherwise. Entertaining last episode. +2 for hot loli asses. -1 for way too many hot loli asses.


Overall: 4/10

Art

Story
I think the story is ok, it's not the best, but not the worst either. I mean I like the idea of it, but it does take shape of many other romance stories in anime I have seen before. But I do think it's unique in its own right, but what I think is the problem is that it needs unique things and twists to really make it a compelling story (Keep in mind this is my opinion).
Sound
I think the sound/ost is alright,I mean it does not differ that much from other animes, but that is not meant to be negative in any way at all. The sound/ost blends in fine with the anime, but what I think it lacks is something outstanding music, for example like the game Life is Strange, where they really make the music and actions intertwined.\n\n
Character\n
Now I don't think the characters is bad in any way, but I also don't feel they are that unique before. One could argue the sister is very, unique in the way she acts, but I personally don't think it's that interesting. Overall the characters are fine but could get more in depth and unique.\n\n
Enjoyment\n
This is where people might criticize me harshly, but I think the best about this anime is how enjoyable it is. I think it's not interesting, but it's like what family guy is for me. It's a show you can watch and relax looking it. Not necessarily the most compelling, but very enjoyable in its own way. \n\n
Overall\n
I decided to give it 9 out of 10 and you can see the reasons provided above.

I had no intention of watching Eromanga-sensei. When it first aired, I saw the fan reaction, which was largely mixed but clearly indicated it wasn't for me. While I enjoyed the first season of Oreimo, the second season and the OVAs turned into a form of quicksand that sucked vulnerable viewers into bad writing and a bad ending. (There's a good reason why there are multiple GIFs of people destroying their computers/TVs after finishing Oreimo.)
Not wanting to put myself through anything close to that, I put it on my "to never watch" list. However, upon joining the MAL Discord, I found a regular user whocontinuously brought up Sagiri as the best anime girl and Eromanga-sensei as one of the greatest anime of all time. It didn't matter what we were talking about—Sagiri ended up in the conversation. As such, I became curious about Eromanga-sensei - maybe even if it's trash, it could actually have a decent story/be a guilty pleasure like, say, Citrus?


I made the proposal on Discord: "50 reacts and I'll watch Eromanga-sensei." I got those 50 reacts pretty fast, and I'm a man of my word. As such, I watched the story of Eromanga-sensei unfold over a long weekend.


I want my long weekend back.


Rather than be a humorous guilty pleasure, Eromanga-sensei is a cheap imitation of what already wasn't great to begin with, with a bit more of a smut push stretching MAL's "PG-13" rating as far as it will go. (Even still, I'm pretty sure no parent would want their thirteen-year-old watching this.) Eromanga-sensei isn't even the Great Value version of Oreimo; it's the Always Save version of Oreimo. That bright yellow logo always assures you're in for a cheap disappointment.


A good place to start breaking down what exactly makes this series so bad would be the characters. After all, characters can really make or break a story, rather the premise is fantastic or not that exciting. (Why do you think so many people watched a series about girls in a high school music club who more often than not end up not practicing and eating cake?) Eromanga-sensei has a bland male protagonist who for reasons of plot has fallen madly in love with his ear-grating, bipolar wench of a sister. 


Through the entirety of Eromanga-sensei, I couldn't figure out what the true purpose of Sagiri was. Was she a self-insert character for hikikomori who fantasize about lolis? Are some people so into little sisters they'll take even the most insufferable little sister imaginable? Or is this series self-aware of how bad Sagiri is and rubbing it in our faces? "Screw you, we don't even have to try, we'll make money selling otaku this garbage."


Sagiri and her brother aren't the only characters in this series. In fact, her brother builds himself a bit of a harem. However, this series has completely stripped any sort of fun out of the harem genre by making it obvious who's going to win just by the camera angles. No other girl gets as much attention from the camera as Sagiri. She's shot like a model for an especially skeevy company that's convinced her she's going to be a star as they take intimate photos of her naughty bits. 


The best characters—a bookshop worker who defends LNs with all her heart and Elf Yamada-sensei's brother—are sadly minor characters. I did appreciate how Elf Yamada-sensei grew less annoying from her introduction and became the character I was rooting for...unfortunately, things obviously aren't going to go my (or her) way if a season 2 ever occurs.


The show suffers from a ridiculous plot hole in that Sagiri bares her legs, clearly feminine figure, and her voice to her livestream in the very first episode, yet there are still people in her chat calling her "old man" for the rest of the series. There's no way a leak like that wouldn't be all over the Internet. Within 24 hours, someone would have been able to identify who the true Eromanga-sensei was. This may be a minor thing, but it pissed me off and affected several aspects of the series. "Oh, who is this Eromanga-sensei?" Well, that should be obvious!


In conclusion, if you can enjoy a can of Always Save pork and beans for dinner, maybe you have the bar set low enough to enjoy Eromanga-sensei. Otherwise, don't waste your time.

This is honestly one of the most boring shows of the season. Just by  watching the first 4 episodes, I think it's safe to say that this is shit for these reasons.
First of all, the characters are fucking boring. The male MC does practically nothing to make us like him and is basically just there for the male MC position. He's so empty that you can literally self insert yourself as him and imagine a 12 year old girl wanting your D. Okay that came off too much but seriously. What's the point of this dude? I mean he doesn't do anything entirely badbut that's what makes him bad. Because he doesn't do jack shit. He also sometimes annoys me whenever he talks like he's a siscon which in fact he is. Well that's just great. 


Moving on to the female MC. She's just as boring as the male MC. Yes. If you were going to watch this for her (which I expect 99% of people have done) then expect to be severely disappointed unless you like 12 year old girls crushing on a dude who's her brother. Oh wait. No, they're not "blood related". We'll talk about that bullshit later. 


To clarify, this character is like Emilia, the waifu you've always wanted, except she's your sister. If you want a sister having a romantic interest in you then congrats because the male MC is a freaking self-insert. Like, this girl is so dull. What makes it worse is that she's a tsundere. Sometimes, she seems to love her brother then the next day she doesn't. She's so annoying. The only distinguishable and decent aspect about her is that her character design's pretty cute and I can unfortunately relate to her at times but a great character design for a character who's that uninteresting doesn't seem worth it. Another thing to add is that whenever there's fanservice about her, it never fails to make me feel uncomfortable.


So now, lets get back to the "not blood related part". So what happens is that the siblings are not blood related. Wow. What an excuse for the impending romance between the 2. Seriously, did the creators just put that in just so the anime (or the light novel for this matter) would not seem wrong? Because that's what it looks like to me.


Another thing that I hated was the fact that this anime seemed like it took no effort to make. Don't get me wrong, i'm pretty sure the cost for animation is extremely high and probably more than what i'll ever get in life especially due to the fact this is A-1 Pictures for god sake but the main thing that was supposed to entertain me ended up with me wanting to go look at a tree for 10 minutes straight and that would still be more interesting.


Looking back, I found out that this anime is tagged as "comedy" but in no way did it make me laugh. All the times I did laugh was me forcing myself to laugh at what's supposed to be funny. Yes, I actually do that and it actually works. Not for this one though.


I also found out the same creator who made OreImo is making this. So lets compare the 2. Although I haven't watched OreImo (forgive me), I would say from peoples comments about it that it still had a reasonably good plot and likable characters. And it actually had a PURPOSE. Eromanga Sensei, on the other hand, just looks like a 2.0 rip off version with a younger and cuter girl. Guess what that's for? Attracting more people and getting that cash.


Other than that, I actually thought the art was really beautiful and nice. The OP was also pretty catchy and made me break into a smile.


To conclude, this seemed more of a rant than an actual review and i'm extremely sorry but I just wanted to vent my anger that I actually wasted my time watching this. I'm not gonna drop EroManga yet because i'm somewhat of a completionist but when I get the chance to do it, i'm probably going to hate myself (not that I don't already). Obviously, there's still a chance for Eromanga to redeem itself and if that ever happens then i'll definitely take a look and see. If you're a fan of EroManga Sensei, then I won't get mad at you or anything and i'm not trying to insult anyone so once again, i'm sorry. But it is what it is, at least for me.


Edit: Overall score was previously a 3 but I felt that was too harsh as I gave the art and sound a 7 and 6. So now it's a 4/10. Lucky you, Eromanga Sensei

Warning this review may contain spoilers 
First impressions, so I didn't really now what to expect,
This being written by the some person who did Oreimo.
I didn't have the most high of standards for this.
Based on the premise I expected it to be more incest baity.
Which don't get me wrong it still is,
It just less incest baity than it's predecessor.
But that isn't exactly saying much,
When take into account the whole  step brother and sister making erotic story's thing.
Story, 5/10
So in latest incest bait of the season.
Are story begins with Main character masamune  a high school student,
who is above average erotic  light novel writter.
Whowrites not just As a hobby but also to take care of his step sister sagiri who is a hikikomori.

But things  are not looking great for masamune as he is currently in the middle of  writers  block.

Which is preventing him from coming up with the next flaptastic  idea for a light novel.

But not all things are grim as masamune mysterious illustrator ero manga sensei still stands by him even though they never met before.

One day he decides to watch a live stream done by ero manga sensei for the first time ever. 

Only to find out that ero manga sensei is actually his step sister.

So after he goes up to  her room to confirm it.

The two decide to work together more closely in order to make a great light novel series, Which  I expect more than  just creative juices flowing I order to make it.



So the storyline line is pretty much them working together as a team.

To make the next big hit in the light novel world.


at first glance it looks like a very vanilla, copy and paste ,seen it done before multiple times  kind of story.

Which don't get me wrong it is exactly  as i described.

Because a story about two siblings who where kind of distance from each other and then they slowly start developing a closer bond with one another though a hobby or etc.

Is not original or thought provoking in the slightest.

In fact I can list off at lest 10 shows I have seen with a similar concept.


And if I am being completely honest I don't think that this show as the ability or writing behind it to push it beyond  a vanilla story, at lest for me.


Because it doesn't have the maturity like for example koi kaze dose or the sexualized over the top nature like kissxsis dose.

It pretty much dips it toes in the water with out making much a splash.


Which on the plus or negative  side Depending on your preference.

we probably won't get a incest is wincest ending,

Which I couldn't care less about if  they go down that route or not.

But being a brain child from the person who oreimo, I won't hold my breath.

If they do.

But enough an there relationship together we will dive into later.


I think the whole light novel industry backdrop is interesting and it cool the see some of the work that goes behind making light novels.

Kinda like bakuman  except in this context it was  for manga.

But unlike bakuman which did some  sort of a criticism on the manga industry,

Ero manga sensei doesn't want to even though it could.


In fact it kinda praises it a bit to much, Which I feel is a little dishonest.

Considering some of the Shade that happens from  time to time.


Now I know I kinda Been bitching  about what this story could have been instead of talking about what it is and how dose it fair with others of it kind.

And for what it is its very average.

So it's a vanilla show,

the whole brother and sister team making a light novel together  is cute and slightly endearing. 

And a whole lot better to watch than Oreimo sibling duo being assholes to One another. Because that shit becomes a boring  very quickly.


So it's not exactly braking any new ground in any way,

But at the same time it's not done in a way where my critic  side would rip it to sunder and send it to review hell.



I think my positives story wise is that.

It's simple and straightforward, and it honest with what it is.


It's also pretty tame fan service wise,

Well tame for me I guess because from what I have heard though the grapevine that some people think the fan service is a little to much.


But for me personally watching the likes of high school dxd and hentai has pretty much made me mostly immune to most levels of  fan service to the point it's doesn't seem the phase me much any more.

So take the fan service thing with a grain of salt.

It's a positive and a negative for me.

But this is just word to the wise.


But the big negative I have with the story is that it has elements that could make it a little better,

If it wanted to use them.

It's one of those cases where a show on it own it fine but has ideas and elements that could make it a whole lot better than it already is.

Which is the main  problem I have  with quite a few slice of life series in general.


Most slice of life series on paper have some interesting ideas ,

but in practice  is very lack laster at best.


Because most of the time they relay on the common tropes for there plot beat. instead of going outside the box a little.



So Eromamga sensei for me is It's like meat lovers pizza but it forgot the meat.




Characters, 5/10


Main character masamune is very cookie cutter personality wise,

There really isn't much of a personality there.

From what I seen he seems like a normal high schooler who has a passion for writing light novels.

his passion for light novels gives him a little depth, but he still cardboard cutout character who I have seen many times before.

But he's a lot better than the main character from oreimo I say the lest.

Which isn't really saying much, but when it comes to basic characters like him there not much to work with.


His step sister sagiri is a lot better than I thought she would be,

Personally wise she just the shy girl who stays inside way to much for her own good.


Which is something I have seen meay times before, so I wasn't exactly hyped for her character type.


But I thought her whole ero manga sensei was slightly interesting.

Because at first look you wouldn't exactly picture her as a person who would be involved in ecchi and hentai related things.

It's funny to see this shy girl drew erotic art work.

And I find that  difference between her real life and online life really interesting and relatable.


Because everyone has a online and real life persona that are slightly different form each other and i think that pretty relatable especially for the younger generations who are online quite a bit and have these online personas.

Which I am just a sucker for.


Now before I talk about the side characters, 

I would like to mention that the relationship between masamune and sagiri is way better than the relationship in oreimo,

Because there actually good reasons for why  masamune actually give a shit or care about his step sister. 

Unlike in oreimo where they just  live  together  and they slightly share common interests and for most part have this love/hate relationship and the main character just gets involved in shit because he has nothing else better to do.


But in Eromamga for example,

Main character parents are dead so he doesn't have much of family except his step sister.

Some one needs to pay those bills and they  share a common interest together.


So they have a better reason to have this closer relationship together and it actually has a objective which is to make light novels together.

Unlike oreimo which was mostly episodic crap.


So side character are also kinda cookie cutter was well.

There also cardboard cutouts as well.

But there not as bland as I expected them to be.

They have some slight quirks  about them which makes them stand out a bit more,

But it still feels very one note.

Like for example there a girl who dresses up like a elf and plays piano naked and another girl who's in middle school who likes dick or something along those lines.

If you take away those quirks they become the usual tsudare and genki girl.


One character that slightly broke this mold was another character who writes light novels like are main character dose,

Except she more extreme  in her passion of reading and writing than are main character is.

In fact when they first meet she kinda comes off like she hates the main character guts and they kind of come into conflict.

But it turns out she like a super fan of the main character light novel series and wishes it would continue.

Because it was a book series that she enjoyed to her very core.


I thought that was interesting,

It didn't last for long though and it didn't have much build up.

But I thought it was nice to have this.


Another thing I want to meanion that some of the characters seem a little to innocent especially those who are involved in erotic shit.



Art, 6/10


Animation  is alright it's very smooth and well polished.

Backgrounds are Average at best, some scenes they look like they been painted on. 


Artwork looks good, lots of pretty colors which I liked.

Because it not in your face about it.

Even though in some scene it was a little to bright.

They could tone down on the color filters a bit.


Art style is generic light novel shit.


Character designs are fine.


There less sexualized than I thought they would be,

But it would just be that the person who did these character designs hasn't got much of an idea for erotic art.





Sound,6/10


Shockingly I actually like both the opening and ending song,

There very happy go lucky tunes.

Which go well with the show and I enjoy listening to them.

But there not music that I would look for or download on my computer to listen to them bye themselves.


Sadly there not much of an ost.

In fact the ost is the opting and ending sougs.


So probably not worth mentioning who did it anyway.


Voice acting for sub  was fine for the most part.

Don't have anything positive or negative to say about it.




Enjoyment, 5/10


I liked the whole idea behind it and some of the characters are slightly funny.

And some scenes made me lol a bit.

But it didn't really go beyond just a time passer for me.


I will probably forget it in a week after finishing it.


And that all she wrote.



Overall, 5/10

Because at the end of the day it isn't do much that hasn't been done before.

Alright, 
Some people like to expect way too much from simple unambitious shows like Eromanga-sensei.
I think every anime should be judged by it's quality but also by it's genre. Eromanga-sensei is a Romantic dramatic comedy anime with fan service. 
It's the story of Masamune Izumi and his little sister, they have both been living together in their house ever since their parents passed out. Izumi's little sister has not been able to recover from her parents death and has been locking herself in her bedroom for a year and refuses to leave it.
Izumi has to deal with that throughout the story and he is alsotrying to become and recognized light novel writer.\n\n
The art and sound is what you'd expect in 2017 the characters are fun to look at but not really deep at all and the story is decent for a comedy anime.\n\n
Your enjoyment will be defined by your mindset when watching the anime if you  treat it as an entertaining and fun show with no much meaning you will probably love it for what it is. However if you try to take it seriously and know you don't like poorly written comedy/fan service/romance stories just avoid it.\n\n\n
Shows like Eromanga-sensei are much needed and appreciated, they are light entertainment that can distract anyone from a bad week. It's a watch and turn off your brain type of show. ( I am not a native English speaker forgive my mistakes)

I'm going to state this right off the bat, this is not the anime for everyone.  Its draws are the cute-girl moe archetype and its target audience is a mixure of ecchi loves, lolicons, and shoujo manga readers.  People who enjoyed OreImo can easily enjoy this anime as well, but here's the review thus far.
Story: 7
The story is an interesting premise.  A light novelist is working with an insert art illustrator whom of which he has never met in person.  Said illustrator turns out to be the shut-in little step sister who he has been living with for years.  
Theauthor takes a similar approach as Netoge where he forces the main protagonists together in a very obvious 'coincidence' in order to tell the story in a proactive way: 'face to face'.  

EX.  of non proactive: in different cities and communicating only via email/skype/phone.

Aside from that, the story boils down to the main protagonist, Masamune, trying to get his sister to abandon her shut-in ways, all while working together to write and illustrate light novels with their respective roles.


Art: 9

A1-Pictures.  Expect great quality, get great quality.  Not as beautiful as an anime such as Hai to Gensou no Grimgar (I highly recommend).  but definitely better character design than OreImo.  Cute moe girls are undoubtedly cute.


Sound: 6

Pretty average.  Sound track isn't super memorable.  Gets the job done.


Characters: 10 thus far

I see so many other reviews bashing the characters.  I will honestly defend them and say that the characters have a very human traits MANY of which are idiosyncratic and niche traits that only certain people will relate to and understand.  CHARACTERS ARE NOT STATIC AND BORING.  The 2 main protagonists are clearly growing and changing which I cannot understand where other people come from when they say that the characters feel 2 dimensional or static.  Are they genuine?  Yes.  Are they interesting?  Depends on what kind of people you find interesting to be perfectly honest.  

Izumi Masamune:  Hard working onii-chan who has trouble catching breakthroughs with his works.  Writes from the soul.  Has a massive thing for his beautiful imouto.

Izumi Sagiri:  Became a shut-in after grief stricken by the passing of her mother (birth mother).

Yamada Elf:  Overly eccentric popular writer.  Writes for fun, profit, and marketability rather than work.


Enjoyment: 10

This is a personal score as I'm bound to enjoy this series more than the average viewer as it resonates with me at the personal level as an amateur writer and artist too.  A lot of the laughs i get from the series come from how human the characters feel.  Can't say nor generalize all of the series, but it definitely has a situational comedy style to its humor (the best kind of comedy imo btw).  


Overall: 8

Definitely not a 'must see,' but I definitely recommend it to people looking to get a good growth story of two step siblings trying to build a bridge between one another.

This anime has as much fanservice in it as possible, while still not being a hentai. The whole thing is basically just fanservice, actually. Any semblance of plot is just there to give reasons to put in more fanservice. The relationship in the series never really goes anywhere because of it. The little sister barely develops at all throughout the series. Despite all that, I really enjoyed it. I have no idea why either. In the grand scheme of things, it sucks. But I found it endearing in a backwards way. I would say check it out even though it's bad, especially if you likethe subject matter.

This anime is Oreimo, except there's no airs about anything deeper and Saigiri isn't a bitch.  Well, there's some other differences I guess.  This show is more lighthearted in comparison, and it honestly works in its favour.  The drama was the worst part of Oreimo, and without it in this series a constant feeling of bemusement always persists.  Honestly it is skippable, but if you allow yourself to get on, Fushimi's wild ride never disappoints.
Story wise it's like Oreimo, but he clearly wants to bang his sister and she clearly reciprocates.  Hence the conflict present in Oreimo isn't really herein this one, and so it's not the driving force of the story.  Instead, the driving force is the two siblings trying to write a really good light novel, and trying to get the sister out of the room I assume eventually.  It works, and what goes on in an episode is typically more focused on interactions between characters with the pot taking a backseat.  Works in the series favour, creating a light-hearted and more consistently entertaining tone.  Dude wants to get it in his step-sis.  10/fucking10


The art is probably the weakest part of the show, just because it's standard A-1 pictures fare.  There's not much to say about it really, because it's never jarringly bad enough to notice and it's not the type of series that really needs it in the first place.  The characters are all cute as hell and the colour pallet is appropriately bubbly.  My eyes are never bleeding when watching this show.  Negatively, there are two things worth mentioning.  One, some (not all) of the fanservice scenes are just bizarre - one time the MC accidentally peeps on a naked girl, but it's just flat loli ass sitting on a piano stool, another time a bit of chest gets exposed by a button becoming undone, but it's only the sternum, literally no breast.  Regardless, it as funny to me.  Two, the art done by Eromanga Sensei is just average.  That's really the only thing that genuinely bothers me since her art is supposedly super erotic, and to that end it's definitely not thicc or provocative enough.  6/10.


Sound, it's styled similarly to Oreimo.  OP is nice, ED is nice, and like Oreimo I actually do like the bullshit tooting BGM.  Not much to say, it's good.  7/10.


The characters are not the same as Oremo, but they do fill similar roles in the story.  Comparably, the ones in this show are much more tolerable, and much more entertaining as a result.  Brother guy is just as dumb as Kyousuke, but boy does he love his sister from the start.  Saigiri is very cute and demure, and she has a decent if typical quiet girl shtick, mixed with some quirky NEET aspects.  Megumi also has a decent shtick, she's exists to try and mug the camera, but the show is aware of it and her humour rests on the audience and the show both not acknowledging it.  Elf is where the show really shines, imperfect ojou-sama characters are always funny and she's always done well.  However one thing with her is that a couple of times she acts chuunibyou, but it really just felt like a rip off of Kuroneko and not an organic part of her character.  Regardless she brings enough to stand on her own.  A colourful and entertaining cast at the end of the day, I like how they all interact.  9/10


Like a hacker hiding behind 27 proxies, maybe my enjoyment may be hidden between 27 layers of irony.  Maybe I genuinely enjoy it.  All I can really say is that Eromanga Sensei is enjoyable in the way only something by a guy who's written nothing but little sister incest light novels for almost a decade can be.  As a result, no matter how flawed, there's just some really bemusing meta and internal aspects at work if you're willing to relish in them.  What is Eromanga Sensei at the end of the day?  Eromanga Sensei is meme, and I can't help but love it.  And as meme, it is only appropriate that this average A-1 LN-adaptation incest show gets a 10/10.  Fushimi is art, and he's done it again.

This is not a plot driven show, don't expect to be captivated by its story elements. What it is (so far) is pure comedy with some of the most impressive (IMO) visuals and character animation from A1 yet. Fan service of a child just strikes me as creepy. I still recomend this show if you want some good laughs but be warned there are some scenes that may cross a line.

MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD:
In case you were unaware, Eromanga Sensei features an incestuous relationship between an older brother, named Masamune, and a younger sister, named Sagiri. The show likes to constantly display erotic panty-shots of the younger sister of the story who is fourteen years old. That alone should be able to tell you whether you’ll like the show or not. However, I think there are some good points to bring up about this show.
Story:
The story itself isn’t bad. I wouldn’t say it’s entirely interesting, but it isn’t terrible. Basically, the story follows the life of Masamune who hasn’t seen his shut-in sister, Sagiri, for years.Eventually, they both find out about each other’s hobby and the story progresses forward as Masamune tries to get Sagiri to come out of her shell. While the concept of the story isn’t terrible, the transitions between the scenes are. You’ll find that some scenes just end sooner than they should or you’ll find that scenes usually end with a pity-laughable joke. The sub-plot on the relationships between Masamune and some of the girls who find an interest in him feels tacked on and ends inconclusively. The relationships practically find a "resolution" almost immediately after being introduced.


Characters:

At first, it seems like every character is an archetype, and that’s exactly right. The side characters are pretty forgettable. The main characters, Masamune and Sagiri, are… okay. They aren’t particularly interesting, so there isn’t much to like or dislike about them.


Music and Sound:

For as clunky as this show is, the music direction isn’t bad. The OP and ED are both really nice to listen to and even some of the background music can help establish a comedic atmosphere. The sound effects themselves are pretty effectively used, at times, to convey the silliness of a comedic scene.


Art and Animation:

I thought I would like the animation and art throughout the whole show, but I was surprised to find that I didn’t. Sometimes, it feels like certain movements are stiffly animated. The lack of movement in some scenes is also noticeable and takes away from the immersion of the show.


Overall:

I know I didn’t exactly rip this show to shreds, but aside from it making me extremely uncomfortable with all of its fan service, the show itself doesn’t try to be incredibly unique. Sometimes, you’ll find instances where the show is trying to be unique only to be met by a panty-shot five minutes later. I can’t rate this show any lower than I have. Its music and sound design is good. Its voice acting is serviceable and the animation wasn't awful. While I personally didn't like the premise and while it made me pretty uncomfortable at times, I think this show is objectively (slightly) below average, even if you do like this particular kind of fan service.

Just wanted to write a quick review just so I could express why I'm confused at the hate for this show. It will contain SPOILERs so just beware.
1st off: They aren't related. 
2nd off: They have barely ever spoken to each other,how could they have possibly ever formed a brother/sister relationship?
3rd: Sagiri explicitly states that she DOESNT see him as a brother from the very beginning.
In episode 8 we find out that both of these characters issues have been created from unsolved trauma from their parents dying. Izumi craves a family because he is afraid of being alone and she WANTS to be alone butfinds people she wants to spend time with anyway.


Their two stories intertwine and turn into a pure and genuine loving relationship between 2 UNRELATED people who both need each other to deal with the loss of their parents.


And yet people hate the show simply because they're step siblings?


Want to note: I dated a girl for 2 years (who then later became my legal step sister). Does her later becoming my sister make me dating her wrong? of course not! The irony is, the only reason our parents met and got married WAS BECAUSE ME AND HER DATED IN THE FIRST PLACE!


If our relationship had worked out I could be married to my step sister. Weird? yeah, sure.

A sister complex? NO, 100% NO!


The show is okay, it has its issues. Similar issues to Oreimo too, but the reason for the show getting so much hate is stupid and narrow minded. "ew they're step siblings, how dare they comfort each other and fall in love"


It's almost like the shows hate comes directly from the fact the author also wrote Oreimo.I feel like if he never wrote Oreimo this show would be considered a fantastic romance anime.


If you like simple romance anime with a little bit of fan-service then you'll love this. Ignore the hate, it comes from ignorance.

Eromanga-sensei, phew, that was definitely a fun time. I know by many it is considered a trashy fanservice show, and yeah, it is a trashy fanservice show. But I still had a good time. I think overall, I didn't think the show was about the whole "Sibling Bonding" thing as it was more about Light Novels in general. I dunno, I kinda just gained an interest in how light novels are made because of this show. 
I think that's what I liked most, the passion that is expressed through the entirety of the show. The passion to write, the passion to draw, all of itis pretty well expressed in my honest opinion, and even if that's not the primary focus of the show, that's what I took from it. 


The fanservice was well... fanservice. I don't really mind it that much, though I don't think the fanservice was 100% necessary for this show. I think the only drawback would be the forced "Sibling Bonding". While I get that it is what the creator of the show is most known for, I just don't think it really sticks out to me as much as the light novel creation and passion part does. 


As for characters, they're alright. Not anything to really make note of, I mean you've got a token loli, a not innocent (but is still completely innocent) school girl, an elf girl, and a traditional Japanese woman. They're kinda just... there. I didn't care too much for them. The same goes for Masamune himself, though I do like his passion. 


For a final verdict, I give this show an 8. I enjoyed this show, and I liked the underlying message about light novel creation, but the characters and story weren't really of much note.

This show is a trainwreck. It's so boring, so dull, has mediocre art at best, and the characters are garbage. There's also no solid story, like, at all. Overall, I will give this show a 2, for I really liked the opening and ending songs. Other than that, this show was just loli bait.
Story: 3/10

He wrote a light novel, but in the course of the story, it never getsfinished, and the story is left open ended for a possible season two (which I really do not want.)


Art: 5/10


The art is typical A1 pictures art, with the same face syndrome. It's not the greatest but it's not the worst I've seen by far. The art gets a pass, although it's nothing special.


Sound: 9/10


Great voice acting, I must say however. The voice actors sound like they're having fun. The voice acting, along with the opening and ending themes, made the show just a tiny bit more tolerable. 


Character: 1/10


God awful characters, all of them are annoying or cliche. Izumi is boring, Sagiri is annoying, Senju is bland, and Elf Yamada is god awful, and annoying. The side characters are also boring and unmemorable, but at least they were less annoying than our main cast. Out of the main cast, the only one I can tolerate is Senju, because she doesn't appear near as much, and doesn't have an annoying personality. She's still boring, and not really that memorable however.

Overall: 2/10


Don't waste your time on this show. It's boring, unfunny, and the characters are annoying.

Ok, this is my first review, and I'm going to be writing this under the assumption that the reader hasn't already watched Eromanga-sensei, and is trying to figure out if they should watch it or not. (I've watched it twice.)
First, if you're turned off by the incest genre, you probably won't appreciate this anime. They make it very clear that not only are they not blood-related, but the relationship as step-siblings is tenuous at best, to the point where they can barely say they know each other. If that's still too close to incest for you, then you'll probably want to look elsewhere for entertainment.
Second,yes, the characters are young. If you aren't into anime that deals with romance between kids that have just entered puberty, you probably won't appreciate this anime. To be clear, I would consider this show just a bit too risque to be family friendly, but I definitely wouldn't consider it obscene. It gets a bit sexy at times, but it's not porn.


If you think you can get past those two points, then I highly recommend this anime. It's beautiful, fun, emotional, exciting, adorable...it's practically a beacon of all things positive.


Now, to the ratings. It doesn't feel right giving something 10s across the board, but I can't justify giving it anything less, so I'll try to explain each category as best I can.


Story: 10

The story is wonderful, and I absolutely love it. Keep in mind that this show is meant to be felt, not analyzed. It's no literary masterpiece that will be watched and studied centuries from now, and the story certainly borrows heavily from other works, but the execution is flawless. If you're looking for originality, you won't find much of it here. If you're a fan of the genre(s) and want to see it done right, I suggest watching this as soon as possible.


Art: 10

I'm pretty sure the art is one of the selling points of the show, so you're probably already aware of this, but it is outstandingly beautiful. Eromanga-sensei's drawings are particularly gorgeous, but the entire show is just a treat to watch. It's vibrant, beautiful, cute, and a little sexy, and I can't get enough of it.


Sound: 10

The voice actors are about as amazing as it gets, and the intro/outro songs are very upbeat and happy, and suit the show perfectly. Both the OP and ED are at least in my top 5 anime songs. I can't say much about background music, because I almost never notice it. If background music is important to you, you'll have to read another review for that. Sorry!


Character: 10

I love every single character in this show. They're all fun, cute, hard-working, and determined individuals...in their own way. I'm pretty terrible with people, so it's hard for me to convey what makes them so great, but all of the main characters made me cry at least once, usually because I was proud of them or happy for them. If that doesn't get my point across, then I guess you'll have to read another review, or watch the show and find out yourself :P


Enjoyment: 10

This is what the show is about. If you read any of the negative reviews, they're all trying really hard to point out every flaw they can find, but that's completely missing the point. This show was made to be felt, and enjoyed, not analyzed. That's not to say that it was designed to be flawed, it was just designed to be fun, not perfect. And that's plain as day, because the love that the creators had for this story oozes out of it at every turn.


Overall: 10

If it wasn't clear, I love everything about this anime. If enjoyment is entertainment with emotion, then this show is enjoyment in its purest form. I literally could not recommend this show more. I hope you enjoy it as much as I did! :)

Made by the same light novel writer behind Oreimo, Eromanga Sensei is another otaku-themed romantic comedy focused on teenage light novel writer Masamune Izumi trying to bond with his younger stepsister Sagiri, a hikikomori who he later learns is an acclaimed online illustrator named Eromanga Sensei known for drawing erotic female artwork.
Compared to Oreimo that at least believably explored public perception to life as an otaku, Eromanga Sensei opts to go into more conventional territory for its storytelling with all the cliches and pandering you can expect out of many modern anime titles. All the female characters are shown to be cute and following whatevertypical characters types hammered to death from many conventional titles with Sagiri a tsundere, Megumi the genki girl, Elf the ojou, and Muramasa the traditional girl. Masamune mostly follows the doormat nice guy character type typical of rom-com titles and, not surprisingly, develops a small harem of girls that develop romantic interest in him that consist of Sagiri, Elf, and Muramasa. While these four do have some dimension to their personalities, there is little growth they face nor much depth throughout the span of Eromanga Sensei's run as they are still stuck with the same character types they were introduced with when first introduced.


Eromanga Sensei's two particular areas of focus in this series are the light novel industry that Masamune is part of and his relationship with Sagiri. For the former case, Eromanga Series doesn't really offer anything too poignant in exploring the light novel industry as it felt mostly like a backdrop to Masamune's complicated harem situation when Elf and Muramasa eventually take interest in him. For the latter case, the series goes for the same siscon vibe that Oreimo gave off with exploring Kyosuke and Kirino's relationship with both the mentioned siblings implied to have romantic interest in one another. Eromanga Sensei is much more direct and blatant with expressing Masamune and Sagiri's relationship here, yet goes the typical "wussed out" route with making the two stepsiblings so the relationship is more palatable for its audience considering the controversy faced with Oreimo's ending a few years earlier.


But the most uneasy thing for me with watching through this series has to do with the sexualization of middle school girls that pop up at points throughout Eromanga Sensei. Sagiri is only 12-years old within the series and shown to have an obsession with having girls undress and show off their undergarments to use as models for her erotic drawings. In one rather uneasy scene for this reviewer, Sagiri undresses to put on a thong with the intent to use herself as a model for her latest piece of artwork. Even the obligatory beach episodes came off making me feel a bit squicky with Elf and Muramasa donning some fairly skimpy swimsuits. While the series does go about with depicting all this tastefully enough to not make it a full-blown ecchi title, it's still likely to turn away some anime fans who offend easily.


Between the tiresome anime cliches, the incestual attraction between Masamune and Sagiri, and the rather squicky casual sexualization of middle school girls found within Eromanga Sensei, this easily stands out as one of the worst titles I've seen for 2017 thus far. Unless the typical otaku pandering schlock milked to death in recent years grabs your interest, avoid Eromanga Sensei like the plague.

Eromanga Sensei is one of those anime where you would think, "this is just going to be a type of hentai." I was mistaken about that. The art style is absolutely gorgeous, it is super bright and vibrant and makes the anime feel just that much more amusing. The story, even with the sense of incest, was extremely good. I loved the idea of two friends being reunited in the form of working with each other to make the most interesting manga. As suspected, it is pretty lewd. The lewd parts in this anime is actually one of the reason I like it. It isvery innocent in a way. Now the characters, they are pretty stale, at least in the beginning. Towards the end though you really feel connected to each of them after hearing their stories about why they want to become and author or what drives them to draw. Overall this was an extremely well-made anime and everyone should give it a shot.

I would like first state my bias to cute stuff, ecchi, loli. I do not enjoy incest so this series not being one make it a plus.
Consistency: the strong suit of this series is how consistent it is at doing what it intends to do. And without it being repetitive and boring. Though some episodes lacks for some weird character development, which wasn't really anything.
Plot/story - theres like nothing.
Character: well they did their job at the tropes they're are carrying. I loved the whole cast. Mc is likeable, have a clear purpose instead of being too attached to the main heroine. The main heroine iscute, and the highlight of the show most of the time. The art bringing them all together worked well, along with the music and such.\n\n
Character development: my biggest gripe with the series. Unclear, have bad pacing, sometimes hurt the whole episode by making it confusing.\n\n

I don't know why this series got so much hate. It's just a decent harem anime about the LN industry. Think Bakuman. I suppose it's the incest but if you've been watching anime for long, you've already get used to it. Besides, Sagiri's design is very cute and is actually an improvement over Kirino. A far mile better than the likes of Suguha, which feels terribly forced. There's also the lolicon issue but again, if you've been watching anime for long you should already get used to the trope.
Sagir's relationship with his brother is the strong point of the show, I think. There's also theLN industry part which can get amusing at parts, albeit obviously exaggerated for comedy effect.


I don't think it's good, but it's decent enough to provide some entertainment. Unlike some other shows out there.


And hey, it gives a lot of cute artwork of Sagiri on Pixiv, so there's that benefit too.

Inasmuch as my favorite mecha shows are formulaic and entirely an excuse to show big ass robots beating the crap out of each other, Eromanga Sensei largely exists only to provide the audience with provocative moe scenarios and a harem of tsundere girls. This is not a bad thing, but it took some getting used to since this is far from my normal fare.
To give you an idea of what I was prepared for, I discovered this show from H fan art on danbooru. It's probably a good thing this show is not what I expected, because that would just be superbly uncomfortable for everyone.We're treated to frequent scenes of our MC saying something that somehow flusters any given member of his harem, all punctuated with a prolonged "Baaakaaaa!!" At the end of every episode I found myself wondering why I was still watching this show, and before I could ever figure it out the next episode was playing.


It features well the types of internet culture to which many of us belong. Our main girl live streams her drawing sessions and interacts with her audience, and our main guy got his start writing by publishing novels for free online and building a fan base on message boards and comment sections. It also feels very modern. Every character has a smartphone, laptop hybrid, or drawing tablet. This one checks the "Modern technology showcased in anime" box.


When investigating this show to decide if I should watch it, the inclusion of a publishing industry competition element reminded me of one of my favorite series--Bakuman, the manga about dudes who make manga--and was the tipping point that told me I should. Unfortunately, this is really more of a side plot and not very fleshed out. Every competitor they meet just ends up becoming a friend/harem member, effectively eliminating any tension. The backstory about our two mains and their life before each other was pretty heartwarming, and something that I probably would have cried at in high school


As wholeheartedly as I love my mindless mecha action, I can't bash anyone who likes this show. If scandalous moe madness is what you're after, this will feed you exactly what you want.

Not being able to see a loved one for a long period of time, especially family bound by blood or being siblings, will surely bring pain to someone currently having a situation like that. That is a universal fact. Not being in our parent's side obviously has a same effect. Some may suffer ftom trauma, some will get shocked and hate the world and some, will lock themselves in, not being able to get out.
The story of Eromanga-sensei revolves around Sagiri Izumi, a shut-in who haven't got out of her room since the untimely death of her parents. Because of this, her relationship with herstepbrother, Masamune Izumi, became horribly complicated. Wishing to see the face of his beloved sister, Masamune tries all ways in order to make Sagiri come out of her room once amd for all.


In order to sustain their near-broken family, Masamune writes erotic light novels and make them published. However, he faces time-to-time problems such as rejections and that he is barely known by the public. He, however, has a very famous illustrator named Eromanga-sensei that can draw really lewd and erotic arts which is one of the factors he barely passes by. The only thing is, he had never met Eromanga-sensei yet and he thinks of him (?) as a pervy old man. Until a very shocking revelation happened.


It was around January when I read about this anime in the upcoming series at KissAnime. When I read the sypnosis, I was instantaneously impressed and started to wait for April for its airing. And I did not regret my choice. I watched it, and found another masterpiece.


The story was outstanding, great, and somehow hilarious to the point I kept rewinding some of the funny scenes. The story was also unique that I can't stop watching it. I think I watched it straight for 8-11 hours, including rewindings and not skipping the themes. It was also well-executed and well-played that I will keep saying that IT IS EXCELLENT.


The art, mostly the illustrations made by Eromanga-sensei which were lewd were (I'll be honest with this one) stimulating. They were excellent it kind of stimulated me. I don't know why. Maybe I have a lolita complex? Now that would be the wrongest of all wrongs. It is wrong. Truly wrong.


The character designs is one of the things about this anime that truly stood out of all things there is. The arts for each character was truly excellent as well as super satisfactory. The designs for Sagiri, Masamune, Mu****sa, Sh***u and last but not the least, the most pulchritudinous of all designs, E*f (here goes my biased review again) were, again, excellent and great. I. CANT. GET. OVER. IT. Why? Because I'm a fan. A fan that can't get over easily to types of anime like this. One more of its type is OreImo.


The music, OSTs and soundtracks (they seem to be synonyms) and especially the opening and closing themes was also something I can't get over with. Especialy 'adrenaline!!' which was performed by TrySail, one of my favorite bands that create anime music, albeit I don't know any of their faces nor members. I also liked the opening theme 'Hitorigoto' by ClariS so well that I already an earworm. (Earworm is the condition in which you just cannot stop listening to a certain song.)


The characters. They were utterly great. Need I say any less?


Sagiri was kind of a TsunYanKuuDandere if you ask me. (Mix of all for basic types of anime personality stereotypes.) That is one of the most interesting factors you can get from a single character in a single series. Masamune was kind, and caring for his sister, like what normal families must do. The other characters was also unique including thad d*ck-loving orange-haired girl, the weird yellow-haired girl with chuunibyou (Eighth Grade Syndrome. Not a real disease) with elven ears and the most popular light novelist in the series.


If you ever read the review, you wouldn't ask if I had enjoyed it. Me writing this was a long-cut of saying "This anime is so f***ing great that I enjoyed it thoroughly. You should watch it too. Just watch out for e***i scenes that will stimulate if you have XY as the last pair of chromosomes." No, I won't explain what I just said.


Again, if you ever read the review, you wouldn't be asking how will I rate it. Overall, the anime was supercalifragilisticexpialidociously interesting and should be honorificiabilititudinitatibus enough not be the subject of anyone's floccinaucinihilipilifications as an anime. Great story, great art, excellent music and excellent characters. I should also note that this inspired me to create a novel right after watching. To be honest, whilst writing this review, I was also writing it. Are you curious? Please be curious. Hehehe.


Now if you'll excuse me, I'll write more about my novel. It is romantic. Good day! (Night if night.)



Ah yes, I won't explain the long words I used. It's too hard to. Impossible maybe.

If your against loli or incest and such then you will not like Eromanga-sensei. And that is totally ok. But if you are one of those people but you still end up watching the series then youwill be rewarded with some good characters and a decent story. Basically not worth the time if your not 'enhanced' by the Art.

But the feelings of lost family and getting a second chance was well done. But the story lost its mustard after like episode 9 or 10. No conflict and all awkward Romance and fanservice. Character = 8

Everyone else = 7


Enjoyment = 8

I really enjoyed it. Its the kind of anime that I look forward to watching on Saturday even tho its Sunday or something.

Story - Pretty interesting, but almost nothing in the story is important. Sure, incest is wincest but what's the point of this show? At first, I thought the anime setting had a pretty big objective but nope, it disappoints me. 3/10.
Art - I have to say, it's pretty good. The animation's a bit above average. Not bad for an anime that has bad plot. 7/10.
Sound - Wow. Surprisingly good music. I was addicted to the OP and ED. I didn't expect it to be this addicting. 9/10.
Character - Alright, so we have a novelist, and a perverted artist. Sagiri's way beyond Tsundere and I donot like it, even as a Tsundere lover. Remove the Tsundere side, we should've had a perfect perverted imouto. I liked the supporting characters though. 5/10.\n\n
Enjoyment - I enjoyed it quite a bit. Good comedy and sometimes there are romantic scenes that make me giggle like a school girl. 6/10\n\n
Overall - 5/10. Not good, not bad. A perfect time-killer.
