What really carried this anime was the art and characters. The story was present in full after the first few episodes and things were fairly stagnant after that point. Nevertheless, there was always enough content to fill the episodes, and neither did they ever seem to drag on, something common in anime of this cute/slice of life genre.
The art is well-done through the whole thing. It's fairly typical for a modern well-funded series, but it's still impressive particularly the way the characters are animated, they are very emotive and fluid. Each character has a unique and interesting design that separates them in more ways thanjust having distinct hair colors as might be the case in a more low-budget series.\n\n
This series isn't life changing and it isn't spectacular, but it is very enjoyable. It's a quick watch which never gets boring through its first season, relying on cute girls for much of its content, but that's a valid strategy which I thought worked very well here.

A simple non-spoiler review:
I was a fan of anime jokes, but this aren`t making me laugh on certain reason. This is not a good thing though.
Jokes suppose to be funny if it used well, on right places and stages, from what it shows in this anime, I clearly seen how inconsistent jokes are flung around your face, and it scream to be meme anime rather than unique and funny anime. 
Of course we should not take it seriously based on theme and plots, but there`s something wrong with it. Show wasn`t that bad, I don`t really hate the show, but its mediocre at the best. Just hope the sequel wasn`t bad.

----------
Disclaimer
----------
The following review is completely spoiler-free, and is meant for users who are curious about whether to watch the show or not. While I write reviews with this focus, and the goal of presenting the show with little bias, it is impossible to write a completely unbiased review. Feel free to disagree with any of my opinions, and ultimately decide for yourself how you feel about the show after watching it yourself!
---------
Positives
---------
- Meme Value
Let's be honest here, many of the people watching the show during its Spring 2017 season did so because of its controversial nature and the spread of memes that came from itspopularity. Eromanga-Sensei has prime meme material; It's no better summed up than the moment in the show that a random girl shows up and declares that she, amongst all other girls her age, "love dicks". It's ridiculous, even for the scenario; A completely random, "what the hell is going on" kind of statement. That is Eromanga-Sensei: The "What the hell is going on" anime.


- Rubbernecking

Do you ever look up videos of large disasters, and while they are horrifying to watch, there's something magical about them that keeps you glued to the screen? You get a feeling that it's so captivating because you can't believe it's happening. That, and that alone, is what brought me back to Eromanga-Sensei each week this season. They can't possibly dig any lower. They can't possibly be more ridiculous. They can't possibly sexualize these poor girls more. They can't possibly... repeat ad nauseum. It's fascinatingly terrible, in a way I cannot properly describe (although I will describe what I believe makes it "terrible" below).


- Moe Factor

Eromanga-Sensei should not be taken lightly; The show lewds the crap out of underage characters. That can't be said enough. But it would also be remiss to leave out the fact that the show does a decent job of actually making the characters cute (when they're not being bent over or thrown into a skimpy bikini). The art style is clean, fun, and colourful, which works fantastically for making the characters emote in wonderful different ways.


- OP/ED

Both the OP and the ED were very fun to listen to, as well as watch. There were some very cute dances in both, and I sat through them each time!


---------

Negatives

---------

- Ravioli Ravioli Do Not Lewd The Underage Loli

I've previously defended anime's exhausting obsession with sexualizing underage characters, due to some legitimate character design questions. For example: Is it wrong to be attracted to, and view suggestive material of, characters that have the bodies of, fully-formed personality of, and perform the roles of otherwise incredibly adult-like characters? Anime often takes incredibly "mature" or adult-like characters, and subtracts some number between 2 and 8 years off their age for no other reason than to put them in an environment of their choosing, or to pawn it off as "relatable" to a teenage audience. Eromanga-Sensei has some elements of this: Elf, Muramasa, and Masamune all are incredibly adult. They run their own independent businesses, do not attend school, live on their own... you name it. However, the show is completely shameless (and arguably revels) in its insistence of lolifying its cast. It shoves their extreme under-agedness in your face, and seems proud to flaunt it. It cackles as it pulls the characters back and forth between adult and child-like tendencies, seemingly enjoying its audiences exasperation and confusion. And the main character's love interest, his younger sister, has absolutely no excuse for this outright sexualization. She's clearly 12, they want you to know she's twelve, and other than her propensity towards lewd drawings, does absolutely nothing to stray from that point. It doesn't stop the show from shoving her into compromising positions, or undressing her for the audience. It's shameless, even from someone who is happy to take up legitimate arguments for/against stereotypical anime sexualization.


- Failed Chemistry

Once again, Eromanga-Sensei succeeds in its subtle goal of completely trolling anyone who watches it. The cast of characters around the MC form somewhat of a harem, which is neither atypical nor particularly noteworthy. What is noteworthy is the absolute glee at which the show builds up the characters to being somewhat interesting, likeable characters, only to rip it away from you. The creator behind the story is Tsukasa Fushimi; We all know where this is going. The MC is going to end up with the sister, as he always does. And in Eromanga-Sensei, you're given a sister character so unlikeable that it cannot be anything but a very carefully planned out troll, specifically made to make audiences groan and roll their eyes. Sagiri is a completely irredeemable character, with no chemistry or traits besides "cuteness" that make any amount of sense to why she exists. Unless, of course, we're talking bra and panty shots. Suddenly it all make sense.


- Fumbling Storyline

This story for the 12-episode season was kind of all over the place. There's 2 arcs that seem to be somewhat disjointed from each other; The 11th and 12th episode are completely randomly thrown in to round it out. There's small bits of progression for each of the characters, but it's either 0 or 100 mph with the show. Either confess your undying love for a character, or just sit back and do nothing. No in between.


----------

Conclusion

----------

I have a hard time finding a word for what Eromanga-Sensei is. It is endlessly debateable, and I don't think that's going to change any time soon. It's got the memes, but it's also got the underage-sister-romance-lewdness. It's got a irredeemably weird cast, and yet I can't look away. It's endlessly entertaining, but I can't help feel dirty after watching each episode. It's.... provocative. Yes, perhaps that's the best word to use. Specifically, the definition that states "to cause annoyance, anger, or another strong reaction, especially deliberately."


Eromanga-Sensei exemplifies and exacerbates so much of what anime viewers are tired of, yet each week I happily watched the episode and marveled at the ridiculousness of the anime as a whole. It's an incredibly complicated thing to review this show because of it. One side of me rolls my eyes and wants to strangle the author, while the other side reaches for another handful of popcorn and smiles while watching the mess.


This review feels all over the place, and it's for a reason. The show is so provocative, I feel I could write several essays on it, or at least the themes it exemplifies. But I will stop here, as I think doing so is all some sort of master plan by the author. Well played, Fushimi. Well played.


------------

Final Rating

------------

While it makes for nice averages and wonderful sorting, when it comes to reviews I personally do not like direct numbering systems. Instead, I am to answer the question: "Would you recommend I watch this show?". This one was incredibly hard to review and rate, so I'm going to try my best to answer it, but perhaps this is something to decide on your own.


If you are a fan of ridiculous anime, especially ones that centre around "meme value", Eromanga-Sensei is there for you.


If you can't stand anime's obsession with underage sexuality, or believe that anime in general has a few select things that are "ruining anime as a serious medium", steer clear. Way clear.

This show should be called: I can't believe how cute my little sister is.
Not just because it is a copy-paste of oreimo but also because there's nothing more to the experience. If you like to watch moe shows with adorable teenage girls despite a multitude of shortcomings, this might be the anime for you. But if you want dept you're out of luck.
There really isn't anything more to it. There's no plot, just a series of randoms events. There's no characters, just a bunch of vessels for poor fan-service and even the "protagonist" is your classical bland/glorified avatar, whose sole purpose is to move theplot forward.


So in conclusion it truly is as bad as a lot of people say it is. Now it's not a 1/10 simply because the animation is pretty decent and the soundtrack is effective. Therefore i give it a 4 out of 10.



PS: This show is an obvious cash grab, pandering nonsense for lolicons and no one else. So i completely understand the 1/10 scores.

To me, this anime in particular is one of those 'guilty pleasure' anime. You know, the anime that most people think is bad but you would consider great. Well, in my case, I actually quite like this show and it's a good way to spend 25 minutes of your time.
Story:
I feel that it does have a flow to it. Not that it's perfect, but it's definitely there.
Art:
This anime looks quite visually appealing. There's something about it that makes it look cutesy and happy, which I find quite nice.
Sound:
The opening and the ending for this anime are probably one of the highlights of Eromanga-sensei. I neverskip them, and I usually skip over openings and especially endings. They're upbeat and give me the good vibes. The seiyuus have done a very nice job in this show, and I have to give them credit.\n\n
Characters:\n
Masamune Izumi is an author who has been turned down many times, but has hit it lucky a couple of times. He is also a good brother to Sagiri, his sister. Speaking of Sagiri, she is where I think people start to hate Eromanga-sensei. She is a hikikomori (a shut-in) who is also an artist. She has been a shut-in for a year, and why she is like that is revealed in the anime. I like her because I think she's cute, and some of the stuff she says and does actually makes me laugh every once in a while, which is actually quite hard to do. She is VERY lewd however, and this lewdness will turn some people off. Whilst not very memorable, the supporting cast do help the story along and they have their moments where they do shine.\n\n
Enjoyment:\n
I found this series to surpass my expectations quite a bit. I wasn't going to watch it at first, but when I saw people talking about it. I just had to see for myself. I would like to own this series on DVD or something of the sort. I'd say I would remember this show for quite some time before I forget about it (mostly because of the memes this show has spawned)\n\n
Overall:\n
I see why people dislike this show, and I get that. But this is a show that hooked me, and I'm glad that I took the time to stop and watch it. If you can look past the fanservice and see the show for what it really is, then I can safely say you may like this show. Overall, I'd rate it an 8 and would recommend it.\n\n
Thanks for reading.

If you just want to see good art and collect potential waifus. This is a very good anime. I found most of them to be pretty boring and generic. The one I liked the most was Sagiri but not because she is a Tier One loli. She and I share a flaw of character, which is that we both care more about our own selves than the ones that care for us. This selfish behaviour doesn't always show and she can very much be a generous soul. But she has a need for something that demands attention.
Storywise, this anime is very boring and wouldn't interesta puppy bribed with affection. I'd say it has one redeemable mark. It's fairly easy to put oneself in the main male character, Masamune, shoes IF you are a writer yourself. They bring up fairly usual struggles with that profession which every writer faces. I know all too well how it is, trying to climb a ladder with no promise of success. You might too.\n\n
When they show the flaws of Sagiri and her struggle with them, I enjoy it. When they show the work and effort in Masamune's work, I enjoy it. You might have something shared with these characters as I do. Give it a try.

this anime is like a bag of unflavored chips. Sure I'll eat it, but only because i am board and have nothing else to do. 
This anime is also garbage. but like most garbage there is some value in it, but only a little, and its the same thing that you have seen over and over. 
Is the art good. Sure it is its by A-1 pictures, but the anime is running at sometimes a really slow frame rate due to the budget. Also A-1 pictures is known for having the same animation and feel for each show that they make. so it is averagefor A-1 Pictures. 


The story is like a story that a 15 year old would post on Fan-fiction.net if they had a hard on for there sister (no offense to the author). The premiss is that a light novel author lives alone with his shut in sister who has never came out of her room once. Turns out that the sister is the illustrator for the light novel that the brother is making. Hence the story of the show. Nothing to special its just kind of bland because you have seen this story a million times. 


the sound is average. Obviously you have your overused stale J-Pop intro with cutesy animation. The Ending is bad and overly average which is what this show feels like. BAD AND OVERLY AVERAGE. The music during the show is fine, and it is made by Tomoki who's made music for a lot of shows such as Nisekoi so he has experience. but its not like I'll listen to it like other sound tracks like JOJO part 4 or Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood. so yeah the music is stale and unimaginative. 


Another reason why this show is stale could be because of the director who is Takeshita, Ryouhei. Now no one would know about this guy because this is the first show that he is directing so he doesn't have to much experience. 


The characters in this show are fine, but unoriginal and follow the tsundare archetype. many characters follow many archetypes such as the main character who is the generic light novel protagonist who always cares for those around him. then you have the little sister archetype, the tsundare archetype which we have a lot of. Ok lets end this review. So did i enjoy this anime. Kind of, but I would have watched something else if i wasn't so naive. I think this anime is an overrated unsalted cracker that people just eat because they have nothing else to do. maybe you enjoyed it a lot more then I did if so good for you. I don't care. But one thing to keep in mind is to not watch stale garbage like this

This anime is not for everyone. If you have issues with a high school MC having feelings towards his 12 year old non-blood related sister and vice versa then you shouldn't watch this. 
It starts off pretty mild, MC meets imouto for the first time and since then he hasn't seen her in a year. He is a LN author and little does he know that his little sister was the illustrator for his artworks; she also conveniently named herself Eromanga sensei but does not respond whenever he asks her if she is (I think it's supposed to be some sort of running joke betweenthem). 


From there onwards, they decide to work together on his new LN project, and a new neighbour who is a hit maker (Yamada elf) moves right across the street from him. Random coincidence? She's arrogant, tsundere and she likes procrastinating on her deadlines. She teases Masamune a lot and originally kicked up a fuss at his publishing company because she wanted Eromanga sensei to draw illustrations for her new project. Initially an annoying character but becomes quite endearing and bearable after ep 3? 


The other characters include Tamago bookstore worker who is also his classmate and Megumin (who is Sagiri's classmate and class rep who tries to get her to go to school. Magumin is pretty much there for comic relief and fanservice. In ep 6, she goes over to Masamune's place to borrow LNs from Sagiri in order to befriend her. Sagiri then starts drawing her in lewd poses while she is blindfolded and restricted. She even takes her panties off. 


Fanservice levels aren't extremely high but you'll feel like you're going to get arrested at any point in time while watching this as the girls are like.... under 15?  


Good humour, I like the interactions and don't mind all the girls. I really like the OP and ED is cute as well. 


Stay far far away if you dislike loli fanservice and imouto animes. Watch it for the humour and super cute girls. Cliche, but not too bad. Art is very good, I love how they drew Sagiri.

There was a satiric article that said that the author of Eromanga-Sensei, Tsukasa Fushimi, had been cut off by his sister because she thinks he's a creep with a sister complex. 
His 'response' to her calling him a creep was "She's just being tsundere".
I wish that article were true because it writes home everything Eromanga -Sensei stands for; Garbage. Eromanga-Sensei is a trashy show that appeals to the lowest common denominator, only rivalled by Keijo, Monster Musume, and Highschool DxD. The only people who would genuinely love Eromanga-Sensei are mouth breathing otakus who are into lolis and anything moe. 
One would think I absolutely hatedthe show. But that's very wrong. I went into Eromanga wanting to hate it. I absolutely abhorred Oreimo and I expected Eromanga to do the same. The only reason I started watching it was because I needed to watch a bad show after finishing the masterpiece that is Sayonara Zetsubou Sensei. And let me tell you, I'm loving every second of this shit. It's so absolutely garbage that I enjoy it, I think I've gone too far into anime if I'm watching a story about a guy trying to bang his sister.


You read that properly by the way. The plot is about a dude trying to bang his sister. Not only that but every other 12 year old who manages to make themselves a part of the plot are immediately a part of the mc's harem. 


Eromanga is a show for kicks. It's not good because it's bad, but instead it's bad because it's good. You don't want to enjoy something like this garbage but you do and then you write a subpar review on it, only to wonder what the hell you're doing with your life once you realize you just wrote a review on a show about a guy trying to bang his sister.


I'm not gonna bother commenting on the story, art, or sound of it all. Just watch this garbage and see for yourself why I'm in such a conundrum. 


I will gladly pop my MAL review cherry on Eromanga-Sensei and recommend this to anyone who's in the mood for a terribly fun time. 


Just please stay away from your sister

WARNING: LOONNNG REVIEW!
TL;DR It's an alternative style of Oreimo that I have expected that it would gain half loves and half hates. I.E., it's fun for some and boring and stupid for others. However, they've got a cool production making it one of the should-consider-trying animes this season (and Anime of the Season just for me... Alright, no more self-ish opinions).
Alright, let me get this straight. This review, while I am one of those guys that think Sagiri is cute, will NOT be influencedby her cuteness but rather, her personalities and every other aspects of the anime. This review is also influenced by the original novel in terms of comparisons and contrasts.


So, most of you should have already known that Eromanga Sensei is similar to Oreimo. In fact, except the story and Seiyuus of course, everything else is the same. Fushimi Tsukasa, check. A-1 Pictures, check. ClariS and TrySail, check. The main idea is close to Oreimo as well. So mark that on because comparisons will happen in the next paragraphs.


I'll skip the storytelling in 3, 2, 1, ...(Go read description)... There you go. So, in my opinion, this looks like they took an Oreimo main idea (Siblings interaction + extra girls and supporting characters) and recycled it, adding probably untrue novel creators' behind-the-scene idea to it (I mean, I don't really want to believe that most author and illustrator characters' personalities would exist in real-life light novel creators, except for Masamune that I approved his work cycle LOL.) But for some reason, I feel like the story and comedy aspects feel brighter than Oreimo. Like Eromanga Sensei is a 'light side' Slice of Life Comedy while Oreimo is a 'dark side' one. Anyway, I like the comedy in this. But again, because of falls the same page as Oreimo, most Oreimo watchers would at least like this anime while Oreimo haters would hate it so...


I forgot to mention that, like Oreimo, they respect the novel storylines very well. While some moments and aspects have been tweaked to speed up and maintain the flow, this is a good adaption from the novel. They follow the story really well and scene additions add good new point of views to the story. In fact, it did way better than this season's DAT one anime Xebec crapped the novel's script entirely... (You know the name.)


For the art, A-1 Pictures made a comeback after destroying Qualidea Code (which I think they used the budget on songs rather than the anime itself) and some other animes. Look at that, a good quality artwork. Although it might not be #1 this season but at least it's on the top of the list, at least I'm sure it beat DAT one anime from Xebec. I do like the illustrations of Eromanga Sensei and the details of the story art as well. It really gave me a good picture when I turn back to the novel. All in all, great job A-1! But let's hope they won't let us down in the second half of the season! (Oh, and yeah, the joystick!)


The sounds? Catchy. I can't still get that 'rush' tune (or something? I don't know, the one with trumpet) out of my head. Other tunes quite passed on making their appearances. The OP and ED, by ClariS and TrySail respectively (the same set as Oreimo!), are awesome. Hitorigoto express Sagiri's theme quite well while adrenaline!!! feels very fresh and happy. And both of them are catchy too. Maybe next Tsukasa-san's anime adaption could use these two acts again.


And here we go, let's go with the character. Again, while Sagiri is cute, I won't be judging by the fact that Sagiri is cute even that Sagiri is cute. First, Sagiri is a shut-in Hikkikomori who is a bit tsundere to her brother (I swear that I didn't know this while I was reading the novel, really! No, I actually had a little hint.). She's super annoying at sometimes, too. She appears to be super pervert too (she's 'Ero'manga Sensei, by the way!) Oh, she's a Grade 7, huh. Masamune is... eh... A crazy MC. He took Kyosuke's personality, but added way too much of sister obeying trait. He's even... I think I can say this, right guys? He's in love with Sagiri. He actually... Now it's a spoiler, so go watch it. Lrt's not forget he's a high-schooler and a novel writer (whose novels are illustrated by Eromanga Sensei/Sagiri) as well. Yamada Elf is a crazy Kuroneko. Megumi is a super-straightfoward Grade 7 class leader who... likes dicks. Tomoe, the bookstore girl is an... upgraded Manami. At least she's more attractive than Manami. And there's another girl who I can't mention until around episode 7-8 I think? I'll get back to this at the end of the season.


The thing is, again, it's a carbon copy of Oreimo, except for the MCs which, I think it's still close to Oreimo's. And I don't know if the characters goes well for the story. I 75%-ly think so, but you judge. At least, I found someone I like and hate (in a good manner). And the puns and comedy's are expressed well by the characters. The VAs did a great job, too. Sagiri's voice is awesome, although it's a bit shocking for me comparing to when she voices another character I knew.


PS. I see some character development coming. There's something behind the two MCs' current life. No more spoilers.

PPS. To avoid shit ending, Tsukasa decided to say that the two MCs are NOT BLOOD RELATED. So take the word 'incest' away from your head because that's not it. This didn't affect my review anyway.


Finally, the Enjoyment rating. I was an Oreimo fan (until the awful ending) and I had a great time watching this. It makes you smile and annoyed sometimes (in a positive way). While I don't think this surpasses Oreimo, a bit better but not much, but I still enjoyed it as much as I enjoyed Oreimo.


Final Verdict: 8/10

If you're a fan of Oreimo, watch it.

If you're a hate of Oreimo, don't watch it.

If you're neither, watch the first four episodes and judge.

This is a good BroSis RomCom anime, i enjoy watching it so far. But i'don't understand why there's so many people hate this anime. I started this anime a couple of days ago. And today finished the whole serie + OVA. But for now i'm gonna review this serie. Its was a good serie to watch and did enjoy it alot.
Story: Well...the story was easy and good enough to follow. Story in short, its all about Masamune and Sagiri aka miss. Eromanga. And the everyday struggle between them. Miss. Eromanga is a little bit a neet. And her brother Masamune is writer for a manga serie. And takes control of the household. They are not blood related and well...they are getting close and learning from eachother.
Art: Art is goodenough and watch easy. The characters are well detailed. Just standard anime art for me.


Sound: Opening and ending are catchie. Not to bad to listen (even I got the opening on my youtube playlist). The sound in the serie is just good. Nothing to say more.


Character: Ok...now the fun part: Masamune the male protoganist is really a nice guy. Carefull and a die hard manga writer. He's one of the girls favorite (cough...no harem?). I did enjoy him alot. Not one of those greedy or anoying boys.


Sagiri otherwise is a young girl and is a neet. Very shy person and cant really talk with people face to face. But...I was a little bit thinking...maby she is a little bit autistic. And why i'm saying this? Because first if got autism by myself. And i'm seeing some part wich can be related to it. And well she is passionate about one thing. Wich is a little bit awkard. But I like this person also. She is a great girl.


The Support characters were fine to. There were no one very anoying. And much of funny thing happens between the main and support. Great work from the makers.


Enjoyment: Ok if watched in a few days. But it was fun to watch. Easy story to follow and not much boring stuff.


Overall: Shall I recommend it to you people? Yes!!! If you like to watch comedy with a little bit brother sister love. (They are not blood related!!!!). You will enjoy it. Maby for the people who wants to see drama. I think its not the great one in the genre. But if you like to watch a chill anime. And where you can put your mind to 0%. Then this anime is for you.

"Anime is trash, and so am I" - Socrates.
Let's address the elephant in the room, if you're absolutely not comfortable with incest, go right ahead and ignore this. No judgement. I only watched this because I have grey borders and a deadly curiosity.
Eromanga-sensei 's greatest strength is it's characters., ignoring the incest traits. In fact, I quite enjoyed the characters especially since the secondary characters really stole the show. Strongly fulfilling the 'entertainment' part of the show.
The story is alright, mostly serving as a means to watch the characters at their most interesting. Production wise, everything is good from art to sound.

Yeah, I actually liked this quite a bit, at least it made me keep wanting to watch it and know what comes next without feeling like dropping it after one episode. I liked the relationship between the characters and there was very little that I hated about it. It wasn't the most amazing thing out there, but it was truly good in my opinion. Oh, and I prefer this over oreimo, not that I care much since I never liked that show much from the start.
So, I feel like this is actually getting a lot of undeserved hatred, it might not be deserving of apublic score of 8+, but it certainly easily hits the mark for a 7+ score, yet it's at below even 7, even average shows gets more than this show but offers so much less. It just seems like this show easily offends certain viewers who shouldn't be here in the first place yet somehow decided to watch it just to bitch about it. Complaints about things like it being full of lolis, the often lewd humor, that it's not as good as oreimo or that it's the same/very similar(surprise, surprise) and thus shouldn't be allowed to exist or perhaps people who dislike the general idea of pseudo-incest or incest relationships, many also dislikes how it's kinda cliché.


However, what I wonder about is what the actual f*ck these people are even doing watching this? Is it purely out of a desire to hate on something they didn't want to watch in the first place? I mean, these things are EASILY discernible with just a quick glimpse at the summary, the title, the cover image and the author, so why bother watching it if you're not into that kind of stuff? That'd be like someone hating shoujo manga going out of their way to read them just so they can say how much they hate it, stupidity at its finest.


Well, whatever. This anime has a pretty cute, innocent relationship between all the characters, almost every character that was introduced was also likable. It's not that deep, but that's what I expected when I started watching a lighthearted romcom. I found the setting and story to be interesting, nothing truly exceptional but it still made me enjoy it a lot. The art was good, as usual with modern anime, the sound was so-so, the characters each felt alive and full of energy instead of feeling like one dimensional robots. I recommend watching this, truly enjoyable. Not sure if it could keep up the same quality for a second season as many novels/manga/anime tends to get way worse when the story progresses and there's many changes happening. It's a solid 8/10 for me and that's pretty good from someone who is strict about trying to give a fair score and would never give a 10/10 or 1/10 unless something is utterly flawless or horrible beyond words unlike so many other people who give 10/10 if they like it a lot and 1/10 if they dislike it a lot without actually caring about if it's TRULY deserving of that score.

From the man and studio who brought you Oreimo, here comes... yet another love story between siblings. Except this time... THEY. ARE. LEGAL. Lol.
STORY
Eromanga-sensei is about Sagiri and her big brother Masamune, who she completely ignores (just like a certain Kirino...). They both live in the same house, alone (they do have guardians but they don't live with them). Masamune is a professionnal author, he works hard to earn a living for him and his sister (despite her ignoring him). The illustrations of his books are drawn by a certain Eromanga-sensei, and as the name suggests... the pics are hot.
One day Masamune realizes that thisEromanga-sensei is none other than Sagiri, his little sister. Then starts an adventure that will improve their relationship (just like a certain pair of siblings...). They will quickly fall in love with each other but their being siblings will make things complicated (again... just like in Oreimo). Aside from those two, a lot of feminine characters are here and will, of course, fall in love one after another with Masamuna (a harem, just like... you got it, Oreimo).


Enough suspense. Eromanga-sensei is a complete rehash of Oreimo. But when Oreimo had much more than a love story to tell (Oreimo is about tolerance and society pressure), this story has nothing else but a romance between a siscon and his perverted sister. The main pitch may make you believe it will be about writing... and to some extent, it does show the life of a Light Novel author in Japan.

Now, the story itself isn't necessarily bad. The romance is assumed from the beginning, and the harem isn't that much annoying. It could be worse.

But really, the fact remains that it is just an empty remake of Oreimo. For a romantic comedy, it may be enough. Personnally, I only watched this for the comedy, so I don't really care about the story. I do find it's a shame that the story doesn't tell much.



ART

On that point, there is nothing to say. Eromanga-sensei has the same style as Oreimo, except it's much better (because it is more recent, obviously). It is a candy in the eye, and the chara-design is cool. Sagiri is so cute! I also like the fact that Elf is actually a real-life elf (with pointy ears and a bow xD).



SOUND

Just like Oreimo, the songs are made by ClariS, so it is catchy. As for the OST itself, it does the job, although I don't keep any music in mind. It doesn't ruin the show, so that's fine.



CHARACTER

Just like Oreimo, the characters have strong traits. They are quite cliché, but for a romantic comedy that's ok.

I don't really like Masamune, he's a pure siscon and has no particular quality. He reminds me of Kyousuke in Oreimo season 2. As a big brother myself, I don't really respect Masamune. He let his own sister shut herself in for (at least) a year! And once he's met her, he quickly becomes a lolicon...

Sagiri, on the other hand, is really nice. The character has been created as the exact opposite of Kirino : whereas Kirino seems perverted but is actually innocent, Sagiri looks innocent but is actually a huge perv'. I'm not fan of loli stuff, especially when it involves sexual content (although it is quite implicit on that case). But despite that, Sagiri is cute and her progression is interesting to follow.

As for the secondary characters, Elf and her brother are fun (probably the funniest in the show imo). But the rest is nothing really memorable.



CONCLUSION

Eromanga-sensei is basically Oreimo but with a legal romance and without any deep message. It is funny to watch for its embarrassing situations, its funny characters and other anime references, just like Oreimo. But it will also not make you think as much as Oreimo.

Also, just like Oreimo, I feel like it should have ended before the actual end. The 11th episode would have been perfect to stop. The last episode isn't bad, it just doesn't fit as an end.


Finally, the ONE thing I really regret, is the lack of realism. Oreimo was impressive on that part : the characters really felt real. IRL I know much more Kirinos or Ayases than I do Sagiris or Megumis. I mean, let's be frank, girls aren't as cute once they've become teens. Sagiri is 13 in this anime, but she looks much more like a 7/8 years old, which kind of breaks the immersion in the story and makes the romance creepy when it's actually not (in this case, this is a love story between a 13-years old girl and a 16-years old boy, and thety're not blood-related).

Also, the fact that they're all PROFESSIONNAL whereas they aren't even 18, it's just too much. In Oreimo, they were mannequin, and teen mannequins do exist IRL. But 16 years-old who sell millions of her book? Nah.


Anyway, this anime is worth a try. If you know Oreimo, don't expect too much.

(This review has been adapted from my blog/reddit thread. Spoilers ahead!)
Names are a vital part to our day-to-day lives.
Mostly because they allow us to identify others. Take myself on the Internet. I go by the name “Banjo” and have done so since I first started taking part in the community. But it’s not just for people. We name pets. We name foods in the wild. We name tracks on a music album.
Without names, we’d be left with describing something without really pinpointing the thing in question. “The dog the Johnsons’ got.” “That one red, rounded fruit.” “That goofball anime writer that always starts his reviewswith a prologue and an anecdote.” Clearly possible to do so, but names make it easy to quickly and accurately specify what we encounter.


Same goes for Eromanga-sensei. Its name (formally a title) instantly selects which anime a person is talking about in a conversation. Coincidentally, the name also makes it a simple method of determining which show to chuck farther away than a poison apple.


STORY


In Eromanga-sensei, a middle-school boy named Masamune lives with his younger sister Sagiri. Having lost their parents, he works as a light-novel author to support the two of them, and she locks herself in her room almost without a peep. However, Masamune soon learns something surprising: that Sagiri is the famous, perverted online artist named Eromanga-sensei. The same person who draws the illustrations for his own very own works.


This revelation begins the anime on the right foot, thawing the awkwardness of their relationship. Unfortunately, the follow-up melts onto the floor as a bunch of unwelcome puddles that the show gladly stumbles into with each subsequent step.


It muddies its feet first by stepping in blandness. Uneventful competitions and the light-novel approach in general decline the plot’s desire to give the audience appreciable content. For example, the show doesn’t share the details of the stories the characters compose despite how important they are to those reading and writing them. While the process behind their creation (sitting down at a table and clacking on a keyboard) may not have excitement, the story’s decision to ignore the embodiment of the characters’ thoughts and feelings only serves to raise an eyebrow.


Not to mention the constant, weak dialogue about creating something “super-interesting.” They have means. They have skill. They have reasons. So, trading in their penchant for prose and replacing it with the most vague, non-descriptive way to explain the passion behind their projects only further dirties the anime.


Failed drama also swamps the ground, causing Eromanga-sensei to slip and fall some more. Take episode three. Masamune talks with Elf on her mansion’s balcony about why he became a fan of hers to begin with. How her novels let him laugh, staving off melancholy that took over his mind after his parents’ (his dad and step-mom’s) deaths and Sagiri’s reclusion.


A potentially touching scene – but it lacks weight. The anime does not emphasize his loss as a conflict or even something important to the plot. Indeed, it’s rarely brought up at all (especially in the mid-to-later portion of the season), seeming more like an excuse to have Masamune and Sagiri alone together in the same house than a source of drama.


Or take episode four. On that same balcony, Masamune jumps from it to Sagiri’s own balcony in a demonstration of happiness. Again, such a scene should make for a dramatic or at least standalone moment. But instead, the outcome is the “classic” guy-falls-on-top-of-girl scenario, killing any momentum such a moment may have carried in his action.


Now, roughly ten paragraphs in, people may be saying to themselves, “That’s not the point of the show. The writing premise doesn’t matter, and the drama isn’t the focus. Who cares about these details in this rom-com, anyway?” If that’s the case, then the “point” must be somewhere else. Namely in either part of that hyphenated word: romance or comedy.


With Eromanga-sensei’s romance, the puddles only grow larger. Quite quickly, the anime makes it apparent that it will tackle a taboo topic: incest. That’s not anywhere near an issue; stories exist to explore any and all subject manners. No, what is an issue is the fact that the anime remains ambiguous in its delivery. And it happens a bunch throughout the show.


They’re actually step-siblings – but they call each other “little sister” and “Big Brother” to reinforce their relationship.


Masamune will say, in episode two, “Stop with the impossible misunderstanding. Just because we live together doesn’t mean brother and sister have a romantic relationship.” But then, in the same episode, he is stunned to learn that Sagiri will not let him wash her underwear anymore.


Sagiri deserves blame as well. In episode eight, she first says, “I’ll pretend to be your little sister for a bit,” but then later says (to herself), “I’ve gotten much further away.”


The harem aspect also doesn’t work. Every girl either implies or straight up tells Masamune that they will for sure be married one day despite his and the show’s clear intentions.


To the anime, either say it is or it isn’t, for there cannot be any in-between here. Even disregarding the wishy-washiness, a topic this controversial, portrayed with such realism, requires a certain level of tact. But the anime does not provide that. Instead, it showcases indecent scenes with Sagiri (and the other characters) that have no purpose or place in a narrative attempting for believable romance and grounded drama.


“Hold on, bub. The ‘romance’ is all memes. It’s whatever, too.” All right, fine. Excusing the drama and the romance, that still leaves the comedy.


Surprisingly, the comedy does manage to shake off some of the residue from all the puddles it has waded through thus far. A scene like Sagiri frantically slamming her foot on the ground to signal her hunger to an under-time-duress, can’t-hear-her Masamune incorporates the premise in a funny way. The male side character author, who joins their party before the festival, brings a couple laughs when he gives the audience a somewhat outside perspective of the crazy people that they have grown accustomed to and he has now befriended.


It dries off with more funnies, too. Its ecchi jokes about penises. The running gag with Sagiri’s door always swinging open and smashing Masamune’s face. The show “rewinding the tape” as Elf double checks that he is really her next-door neighbor. None of these scenes are downright hilarious or extremely clever, but, all told, Eromanga-sensei finally has a net positive on its hands with the comedy it touts.


Yet when so much of the show (the drama and the romance) must be excused to make way for one passable part (the comedy), it’s tough to justify its merit when it would otherwise be hard to find at the bottom of those puddles. And so, ultimately, it stays soaked from head to toe.


ART & ANIMATION


In general, Eromanga-sensei does not skimp out on movement, giving Masamune and the other characters the reactions and charges they require.


For example, in episode eight, Elf flicks Masamune’s head with her finger to knock some sense into him, and his momentum pushes him backwards while his hands swiftly cover his face. In episode five, Elf rolls around in a sporadic manner to highlight her expressiveness. And Sagiri’s temper tantrum in the second episode is another quick example of the show’s strong animation.


On occasion, though, the anime elevates the fluidity even more. These short segments stand out as both a big positive and a big negative. On the positive side, the noticeable increase in animation gives the show a sharper, skillful look, like when Sagiri stands on her tippy toes while wearing her slippers at the beginning of episode eleven.


On the negative side, these scenes often exploit the situation to an unnerving degree. In episode six, the camera hangs low, aiming at Megumi for a peek at her crotch as she lifts herself up from her bed. Or how, in episode four, Sagiri tries on risqué pink lingerie to model a new pose for her art. In short, these scenes are uncomfortable and unnecessary no matter how much the strict animation flows.


Outside of movement, the anime includes other moments or techniques that improve the artistry. Cute dances from Sagiri in the opening track and the ending track give those songs a fun backdrop. Certain camera cuts capture the comedy, such as when, in episode eight, Masamune’s editor is one extra shot over, forcing the field of view to swing across one more time. The background changing from Sagiri’s room to the hallway without a transition in episode three as Sagiri kicks Masamune out also improves the direction of that scene.


Speaking of backgrounds, Eromanga-sensei doesn’t change its location often, so it doesn’t have very many (if any) chances to showcase its setting and the art itself. While that may explain the extra attention given to the animation, the show still has to appeal elsewhere. Particularly in the characters’ designs.


Said designs are not too shabby. Masamune’s dark-green, spiky hair and plain style are boring, but Muramasa’s yukatas and bandaged fingers give her a mature and skillful vibe (respectively) that fits her character. Sagiri’s colors (teal, silver, pink) meld nicely together, and Elf’s golden locks, frilly dress, and actual (never noticed) elf ears give her the most interesting design of the group.


Altogether, the art and the animation are usually above average in their execution, but those overly exploitive scenes really take away from what the visuals present.


CHARACTERS


In some regards, the best part in all of Eromanga-sensei is Sagiri’s arc and her gradual change to a (slightly) sociable person.


When the season begins, the show characterizes Sagiri as a talented artist with a knack for lewd drawings. A characteristic that often spills over into her actual life where she cannot repress her need for artistic inspiration from other girls. However, the most important detail about her is the reclusion she sticks to.


The loss of her mother and step-father pushes her into a dark hole. Therein, the only solace she finds is in connecting with people across the world through the Internet under the guise of her famous online persona: Eromanga-sensei. But she cannot even talk to Masamune face-to-face let alone leave her room. In essence, she needs help.


Once Masamune learns of her secret identity, he provides just that, doing what he can to slowly ease her out of her reclusion. He invites over Megumi and Elf who share common interests with the girl and who help her out in their own, supportive ways. He teams up with Sagiri again on a brand new light novel so that they can collaborate together. And, in general, his kind words and sincerity in wanting her to face her fears gently lead her out of her room.


This approach works, but, again, it’s all very slow. She starts to open her door more regularly, and she even starts talking to more people besides just her fans and Masamune (albeit with her signature mask still on). It culminates into an important scene for her character in episode seven. Muramasa wants to defeat Masamune in their writing competition, but Sagiri, having none of that, not only walks down the steps of her own free will but also yells at Muramasa for trying to wreck the dream they pursue.


Eromanga-sensei tries to make such dreams an important part of each character, but they don’t contain much in the way of a thematic presence. They relate to the characters, and they voice them at one point or another, but they are not a source of exploration or top-tier focus within the show.


Still, they are at least consistent. Masamune wishes to watch an anime adaptation of his collaboration with Sagiri. Elf strives to create the most interesting novel in the entire world. Muramasa desires to read Masamune’s genre-specific works.


With dreams in mind, Sagiri works hard to make Masamune’s a reality as he does the same while away at the retreat. She doesn’t follow through on greeting him home at the entrance to their house when he returns, but the two reminisce about their early days while “walking” through the city. How they (unknowingly) spurred each other on to become the artist and writer that they are today after so many years (with another trip down the stairs too).


By the end of the season, Sagiri willingly “invites” Elf and Muramasa to “play” in her room. Without a mask on at that. She even opens her window to say “See you!” to her newfound friends as they say goodbye as well. A metaphor of sorts for her finally opening up and overcoming the troubles that have clouded her mind.


To reiterate, talking to people, walking down some steps, and opening a window may not seem like much. People do all that and more within a few minutes in a single day on a regular basis. But, for someone like Sagiri, who has battled with trauma for a while now, these incremental changes make for a noticeable, healthy improvement to her character and a welcome sight to see.


Unfortunately, beyond Sagiri’s character, the rest of the cast falters. Masamune may be there to encourage his sister, but he doesn’t receive as much individual progress, existing more so to let the other characters play off him instead. Elf is loud and somewhat arrogant, but the anime’s attempts to expound further on her person amount to spilling her thoughts in a confession at a firefly-lit pond. Muramasa does the same during her second or so encounter with Masamune, giving the audience backstory, motive, and a resolution in one fell swoop to make room for her secondary seat on the train to nowhere.


Eromanga-sensei also juggles with too many extraneous characters: Masamune’s editor Ayame, Elf’s older brother Chris, the other male light-novel author Kunimitsu, the bookstore girl Tomoe.


These characters are technically relevant in their tangential relation to either the main cast or the fields in which they work, but they do not do enough to warrant their place within the anime. They slightly vary up the situations presented, but their inclusion rarely (if ever) impacts much of what happens in the show, taking valuable time away from Sagiri and especially the lackluster remainder of the cast.


Thus, Sagiri is the only character in the story who ends up at least worthwhile. And amidst how much the anime gets wrong otherwise, her arc demonstrates that the show can do something right without needing justifications.


MUSIC & SOUND


A lot of the sound work within Eromanga-sensei reaches an average middle ground.


The original soundtrack demonstrates this argument easily enough. In most cases, it has a hard time supporting its various scenes – particularly its comedic ones. When events become slightly more hectic or otherwise sillier than normal, circus-esque tunes kick in, overbearing the interactions with their loudness and their unfitting nature. Yet the OST can prove its worth. A lighter piano-and-flute melody appears every so often, accentuating the sincerity of the show’s scenes whenever it plays.


Similar words apply to the voice acting. Akane Fujita as Sagiri hasn’t had very many main roles as of yet, but her cute responses and soft-spoken manner let her thrive as the little sister. Minami Takahashi as Elf also does well with sarcastic phrasing and a holier-than-thou attitude.


In contrast, Yoshitsugu Matsuoka, a veteran among veterans, lends his talent to the anime, but the slight higher-pitched tone for the male teen annoys rather than works. And, for everyone in the VA process, some of the screams out of joy and anger miss the mark.


That initial argument also applies to the opening track and the ending track. Titled “Hitorigoto,” the OP blares its trumpets before mixing in dainty instrumentals, a catchier beat, and harmonized singing. This combination creates a simple first half and an involved second half that results in a passable piece.


The ED, “adrenaline!!”, includes trumpets too, but they take on more of a supportive role than stealing center stage. Plus, the rising and falling in the sounds, the bass and guitar playing, the enthusiastic “Yeah!” shouts, the fun atmosphere of the song itself. Again, nothing special, but it remains much more consistent in its appeal.


So, the OST, the VA performances, the OP, and the ED have parts worth praising, parts that pass, and parts worth criticizing. A combo that places the whole music-and-sound package squarely along that middle ground.


ENJOYMENT


In past reviews of mine, I have brought up my indifference to the loli archetype and how I tune out or laugh off the absurdity of the perversion this medium sometimes tags along with it in the shows I happen to pick up. I tried to do the same here. While I partially succeeded, the problem is its prevalence. It’s around all the time rather than as a one-time thing. The suggestive poses, the deliberate camera angles, the constant reminders of how young they are. Each time it’s ignored, the elephant in the room only grows larger.


That elephant gets in the way of everything else, and that “else” could actually be entertaining.


I like Elf. Her boisterous personality and her teasing behavior made her a nice addition to the cast. I like Muramasa. Her shy, ecstatic reaction when Masamune called her on the phone got the romantic in me cheering. And I like Sagiri. Her “Euaghh!” at the mention of Megumi’s impending arrival and her “I don’t know anybody by that name!” deflection whenever her penname surfaced brought a smile out of me.


Truth be told, if the anime ditched the underage perversion, it would not automatically fix the lack of basic execution in its different areas. Even so, it would have at least given the comedic moments and the characters a chance to shine. To revel in their fun and their cuteness. Instead, that elephant overshadows their chances.


I have one last nitpick, and it really is a nitpick. In episode ten, the characters play a card game, but the illogical rule to always let Sagiri be the leader makes no sense. If Sagiri cannot physically select a card, just give her the last one available. Done. Because otherwise (and as what happens), the scene feels forced and eliminates different opportunities for shenanigans between the characters.


Such an inconsequential detail shouldn’t have bothered me so much, but all the ignoring I was doing made me extra attentive elsewhere in the anime. And what I found was, as the show might put it, “super-uninteresting.”


Eromanga-sensei doesn’t have much going for it, and even what is there doesn’t hold up. The weak structure to its story. The mixed artistry. The lackluster cast. The ill-fitting music. The lost chances. No name drops here. Just chucking it, name and all, very far away.


SUMMARY


Story: Terrible, passable comedy cannot justify the bland events, the failed drama, the wishy-washy romance, the lack of tact, and other negative details


Art & Animation: Fine, fluid animation, noticeable techniques in the artistry, and a couple of nice character designs hide the boring backgrounds, but the overly exploitive shots do not sit well


Characters: Bad, Sagiri’s battle against reclusion sees incremental, welcome changes to her person, but the faulty rest of the cast, from lackluster mains to extraneous sides, either do not receive the same dividends or contribute very little


Music & Sound: Fine, with strengths and weaknesses aplenty, the OP, the ED, the OST, and the VA performances find middle ground


Enjoyment: Bad, could be funny and could be cute, but the elephant in the room overshadows


Final Score: 3/10

Oh god where do I even start for such an anime. Eromanga-sensei is the spiritual successor to Oreimo by the same author and it doesn't even succeed with that either. Many people bash this anime for the constant "Fan service" if you even wanna call it that but my biggest problem with this anime is the god awful story progression. Eromanga-Sensei is about a aspiring light novel writer who finds out his shut in sister is the artist for his stories. The concept is really cool actually it shows is the struggles light novel authors have and it could've made a really good anime butthat's not the focus of the anime its sort of the theme. The real focus is the cringey relationship between Masamune and his little sister Sagiri. Starting from I think episode four they already made it concrete that Izumi is a siscon and wants Sagiri to be his girlfriend not his sister. The story doesn't know where its going because they start introducing many characters that Izumi/Masamune starts turning down I guess Tsukasa was trying to fix the issues from Oreimo where he built up all these girls and made Kyousuke turn them all down. But why even have him turn down the girls just make the girls apart of the friend group or something, its like Tsukasa knew how much people hated that about Oreimo and just made it worse! Also the worst part that gave me a concrete rating on this anime is the ending it was like an ending of every other episode! Were they that confident that this shitshow would get them any bank? Well I guess they were right because an OVA is coming out soon and if we're following the pattern of Oreimo then they would make a season 2 and piss of the community once more. This is actually the first anime that got me GENUINELY angry, just spare your time and don't watch this anime it doesn't know what it is.



In short don't watch this anime there is literally no reason too watch it, not even for the meme purposes, even if your a fan of Oreimo it would likely piss you off even more because the characters from the show appear in the anime as a cameo as like rubbing salt in the wound. The only redeeming quality this anime had was Sagiri is funny at times,and can even be considered relatable, and I guess cute.

I'll admit, the reason I watched the series - with a friend on New Year's Eve drunk as all hell - was to make fun of it. Yet I wasn't expecting it to be half as bad as it turned out to be. I was expecting to at least get a good laugh about how bad it was but me and my friend ended up chatting more about other things during most of the episodes than actually watching the series.
And the simple reason for that is that it's not even "so bad it's good".
It's boring.
What I hated the most wasn't the whole incest plotline oreven how sexualized these 12-14 -year old characters were. What I absolutely despised was how it was claiming so hard to be a portrayal of a writer and an artist and failing so utterly badly at what it set out to do with that setup. The so called "writer's everyday" in the anime is shown as unrealistically as it could have been - Masamune has an all-nighter writing his novel and the next morning he's cooking breakfast for his sister and walking to school as chipper as always, after... what was it, just one energy drink?


I call bullshit.


Same goes for Sagiri and her art. The anime does little to get into the progress of her craft, only using it as a reason for a gag or two every now and then.


My only question here is: why would this anime build a setup of a writer and an artist as the basis of it if they were not going to do anything at all with it?


There was a damn tournament arc set up on one episode and I got excited because maybe they would FINALLY shed some light into what writing is like as a creative process, perhaps show Elf and Masamune bouncing ideas off of each other and working together to better their writings.


The tournament arc was barely an episode long because eh, who cares about that.


I would have far more respect for this anime as a whole if it didn't try to be anything else than what it is - an incest fanservice loli romcom. But it claims to be deeper or more meaningful by tackling the subject of being an artist without actually ever tackling it and it pisses me off.

The story was great, it had you for a second there when they starting to revealing their background stories and how they first know each other for every character except the newly introduced. The animation was great either, nothing special and nothing flaw. The art style was similar to No Game No Life which give a more vibrant color and better color contrast than any other anime making it more lively. The voice acting are nothing special too. The humor are just above right and what I find mostly facisnating is the way they delivered their love or romance. It touched me a little despitethe heavy lewd and fanservice on this anime. Just to make clear, I'm old as Masamune so it wasn't weird for me to watch this (kinda) and in fact marrying or fall in love a 6 years younger than you isn't strange at all, it pretty much like 25 years old with 31 years old which roughly the same as 10 years old and 16 years old. So finally, my rating would 9 - Great!

Ignoring the fact that it contains loli, I disliked how the story progressed so slowly. It was just boring to watch when the whole episode focused on something sexual or just didn'tprogress at all.\n\n
Bottom line: You'll enjoy this if you like loli. If you don't, you most likely dislike it. Ignoring all the loli, it is a decent show but because of it, the show is easily one of the worst ones I've seen.

How can I put Eromanga-sensei like this...
Oh, it's a sister anime, right? Incest... and all sorts of that. If you know Oreimo then you should probably give this a try, because it is extremely similar on how Oreimo presented itself to the world.
Apparently, this anime existed in a world where everyone is somewhat underage. Well, I know that this is between little sister x big brother romance. But, the only thing I can see is a 16-year-old guy getting all those 12-14-year-old cats. So, what's good for this anime?
Let's look at, one thing—it's artwork. Wait, A1-Pictures made this, right? The one who made Sword ArtOnline and such? Right. The artwork for Eromanga-sensei is almost perfectly polished, smooth, subtle motions and great camera movements (if you know what I am saying).


Characters... Izumi Sagiri herself is a perfect waifu, but if you look at her greatly with a menacing glance—she's, somewhat annoying to her brother. Her personality is extremely chaotic. At first, she becomes nice to her brother, then the second she treats her brother like shit. Well, I know that it's just jealousy or not, but if you want a girl with that personality. I don't think it's not a good idea to have one yourself. It's all just personal preference, hm?


The main character—Masamune Izumi is an example of a person with great independence and a strong sense of responsibility. Also, he has a fetish for little sisters (God, what happened to Japan...). He's kind towards anyone and is submissive, granting the demands to anyone.


The story itself, I can't put this greatly. I didn't pick up any important morals in the ending. Well, I ain't gonna spoil you or anything. Find out yourself and let me know what you truly think. So, let me put this—an ambitious high school student who wants to be a great author founds out the one who makes his lewd drawings is actually his sister. A plot that you will more likely not see in real life, hm? Yes. That's the story. Oh, also he meets underage authors, etc.


My overall rating and enjoyment are at least 7.5/10. I like the humor the anime has brought, yet I fairly like the story and its ending. The thing is, this just reminds me of Oreimo. I think that it deserves its 7/10 rating.

(Spoiler Warning )   I came into this particular series just because I had nothing else to watch, however I do not regret that decision at all. I found myself laughing out loud with this quite a few times and that rarely happens with me when watching some anime. Each character is given a decent amount of backstory and time to develop so that when something serious is going on with a certain character I actually feel for them. Take for example Sagiri, Sagiri is shown at the start to be a stubborn introvert that has no interest in speaking to any other people.However as time progresses we see Sagiri grow as a character to a point where she will actually socialize and help the other characters. So this is certainly not the worst anime I have ever seen but it's not the best either.

Eitherway because of the 'siblinglove' aspect, I couldn't help but constantly feel weirded out, it was creepy. This was a cute, very humorous, and enjoyable story about a high school boy Masamune whose father remarries and brings a junior-high school girl named Sagiri into the home as his step-sister.  However, the parents soon leave the picture and the two are left alone in the home to more-or-less fend for themselves.  Sagiri becomes a shut-in "hikikomori" and Masamune is left to provide for her without actually ever seeing and talking to her directly.
You can read the plot details elsewhere but eventually the two siblings begin speaking and interacting together.  It turns out they have actually been working together all alongon-line on the internet without realizing it in the light romance novel industry, a theme that recurs several times over the course of the story.  Eventually other story writers find them and they all begin interacting together in a variety of comical encounters.


Although the story could be compared directly to its predecessor Oreimo as a "Harem" style anime, and is definitely PG-13 due to the subject matter being toward the more mature end of the anime spectrum, there is nothing inappropriate about any of it.  Accusations of incest either direct or implied are completely off-base as there is never any hint or intimation of that kind of relationship in this story.  There is at times expressions of familial love between brother and sister, but it never moves beyond the realm of propriety.  While it is true that Oreimo did move much further into exploring this topic, THIS anime does not.


Two final things:  there were a couple of "cameos" of Oreimo characters making appearances in this anime.  It is clear that the timeline of this story was coincident with the Oreimo storyline.  Also, the story was not ended at all, I would say that it is likely that there will be another season of Eromanga Sensei.  If so, it is my hope that they do encounter the Oreimo characters again, possibly in a more direct way in the next season.


Bottom line:  Enjoyed the series, even if the story was highly concocted and unlikely in the real world.  That's what anime is for.

A typical anime that was just for presenting another possible waifu.
The anime itself does not have a really interesting plot. The whole story is just surrounding around masamune wanting to impress his sister for obvious reasons, restating repeatedly that she is cute yet kept stating that he is just the brother of sagiri.
Yet the anime is still worth the praise due to its art. For a character focusing anime that doesn't really have a plot, it is important for the production group to be able to highlight the character that the author wanted, in this case, sagiri. The production group did a pretty good jobdisplaying the unsocialble  sagiri as the way that the author tried to portrait her in the novel.\n\n
The CV of the characters also did a good job with sound, being able to clearly convey the tone and feelings of the characters have during the anime.\n\n
All in all this is just another  himouto umaru chan that is getting attention due to the cuteness of its main heroine. Its not a bad anime but would not recommend if the viewer doesn't like animes that are just focusing on a cuteness or a certain characteristics of a single character.

So this anime had it's good parts, and it's bad parts. I will say this anime reminded me a lot of Oriemo, due to the brother and sister relationship they had going on. First I will point out all the pros
Pros
1. The art style was actually really good. While it looked generic, when showing Sagiri's art, they made it seem original.
2. The story line wasn't a generic one. It followed the life's of two step-siblings, one artist and one's an author. I won't get into too much detail, but it had a special element to it
3.Sagiri's character development was actually good. They slowly eased usinto her character, instead of rushing her, like I've seen a lot of anime's do.\n\n
Cons\n\n
1. The relationship between the brother and sister was a little weird. While there wasn't really much incest going on, I still felt a little uneasy about it. Even if they are step-siblings, I still find it odd to fall in love with them.\n\n
2. There wasn't really an ending. I would say the last episode was more like a rushed ending, if you catch my drift. It didn't close out the season, some people argue that there will be a second season, but who knows for sure.\n\n
Overall, I give the anime a score of 7. It wasn't a bad anime, but it did have it's negative aspects. Most anime do anyway. But don't take my word for it. Watch it yourself, and see if you enjoy it or not ~

I watched this show to simply understand what the buzz was all about, and now I know this show is garbage with nothing to make it different or interesting from other bad ecchi shows.
Story: The story is literally OreImo but worse. Which makes a lot of sense considering they are from the same author. This story is nothing but incest and pedophilia which only made me feel uncomfortable and disgusted with myself from watching this. The writing is cliche and uncomfortable giving us a lot of moments to joke about how the writingis awful.


Characters: The cast is nothing but cliches we've seen before in other better shows. The shy tsundere little sister, chuunibyou that thinks she's a princess, calm and collected girl, and the dense main lead. The worst part is the other two girls in this ''romantic'' plot are much better then the little sister who literally sexually harasses other people. All characters are genuinely annoying with no real reason to like or root for the cast. 


Art and sound: The art and animation was pretty solid coming from A-1 pictures. Though the character designs are pretty generic I like the presentation. The animation was good, but not stand out. The music was forgettable with not many stand out pieces except for the fun OP. The voice actors did a okay job at playing the characters,but nothing outstanding.


Final Thoughts: This anime is a true garbage pile with no reason for people to watch. Nothing about this show is stand out or is interesting. I would say pass this show if you're looking for a show that is intriguing or fun. If you're looking for a show with awful writing that will make you feel uncomfortable then this is the show for you.

Story : 2/10
Honestly I think the show could've gone well if it didn't go cramming so many god damn premises down your throat. I went into the anime knowing nothing about it honestly, I saw some art of the girl drawing I chose to use for my Desktop wallpaper and chrome themesince I'm quite into art myself.


The first bit of the story is a nice little thing of two people who've lost a close family member being forced to live under the same roof and becoming brother and sister. It's an almost interesting premise, the writer with a one-hit-wonder series stuck in a rut and his sister who refuses to leave her room and uses art as a way of therapy. My initial thoughts were that the anime was going to go into a story line where they were going to help each other recover from their grief and end up gaining friends along the way.

Then it got... Confusing.


It started shoving story lines that could've been down your throat, from the confusing harems and glimpses of what could've been the main premise and then the incest but wanting to just be brother and sister then wanting to hook up with her was just... Confusing! In the end it just turned out to be this pile of gloopy slime that didn't have... Anything! I just sat there through the twelve arrogantly long episodes not knowing where it was going. It had potential from the first episode, it could've been great and about how they were healing but it was just fan service, a bunch of characters defined only by how Tsundere they are with no plot whatsoever apart from the 'Let's all achieve our meaningless dreams with no point' cliche.  

Absolute dull, painful garbage.

His sister is alright, annoying how she changes her mind constantly and is so stubborn but I've seen the same character type in other animes I've watched so I didn't hate her.


People think people hate the anime just because of the incest and fanservice over 13 year olds and think this is absurd because of No Game No Life being the same thing, but it's not. Shiro clearly has a crush but it's one sided, but it makes sense as younger siblings sometimes do develop crushes on their older ones before understanding how sex works, but it's entirely one sided and that makes it kind of endearing at times. Don't get me wrong, Incest is nasty business in my book but how their fear of being separated is shown is amazing, how their world seems grey when they're 'alone' and how they can only really trust each other through the trauma they had is actually kind of beautiful and an almost rare thing to be played out so nicely in anime today without it being incest like in this anime.


 In this show it's just the incest and fanservice with no real character development in between, they love each other but want to be siblings then want to hook up and it makes no sense.


Now onto the princess who we see playing the piano naked. 

I hate her. I see characters like her that are just as unbearable but this character.. This... Human being or... Elf... Is just so... Mind-numbingly frustrating. She does nothing but fit the stereotypical Tsundere algerithm and has the audacity to even be considered a character. She wants to marry the main guy but the motivation towards this from the beginning is just so out of order to me. She hasn't got a reason, she just suddenly does.

In the first scene of the first episode we see Masa and Sag acknowledge each other with an almost cute scene where it's more like 'love at first sight'. Elf just yells at him in the first seen with Masa, that's it and that's all she ever does for the rest of the anime.


Senju gave me an aneurysm. SHE IS THE WORST CHARACTER I'VE EVER SEEN. EVER. She is even worse at being a Tsundere than Elf. I can't stress my absolute hatred for this completely disjointed character. She's ridiculous, has motivations beyond reason, and could've been some kind of plot device BUT NO. She at first seems to be the shy and emotionally numbed type but then turns out to be just another Tsundere CHILD in love with Masa. She wants to crush is dream for her own dream, but her dream is to write an interesting story and read it so... What? Then she explains how bland she finds all novels apart from his ones and how annoyed she is at him. The only shot I like with her is when she's leaving and says 'If it's not interesting I'll kill you'. I honestly thought there might be a plot there, she might actually be that insane type that causes the problem in the plot but... No. Just another annoying Tsundere in the harem.


Jinno is just there saying she likes d***s for most of the anime. That's all she is really. A wonderful human being who collects friends as a hobby and celebrates the male form for a job.

The rest are nothing really. Just bland oats.


Enjoyment : 3/10
